speech.speaker: Anthonio.
speech.line: In ſooth I know not why I am ſo ſad,
It wearies me: you ſay it wearies you;
But how I caught it, found it, or came by it,
What ſtuffe ’tis made of, whereof it is borne,
I am to learne: and ſuch a Want-wit ſadneſſe makes of mee,
That I haue much ado to know my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Your minde is toſsing on the Ocean,
There where your Argoſies with portly ſaile
Like Signiors and rich Burgers on the ﬂood,
Or as it were the Pageants of the ſea,
Do ouer-peere the pettie Trafﬁquers
That curtſie to them, do them reuerence
As they ﬂye by them with their wouen wings.

speech.speaker: Salar.
speech.line: Beleeue me ſir, had I ſuch venture forth,
The better part of my affeƈtions, would
Be with my hopes abroad. I ſhould be ſtill
Plucking the graſſe to know where ſits the winde,
Peering in Maps for ports, and peers, and rodes:
And euery obieƈt that might make me feare
Miſfortune to my ventures, out of doubt
Would make me ſad.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: My winde cooling my broth,
Would blow me to an Ague, when I thought
What harme a winde too great might dœ at ſea.
I ſhould not ſee the ſandie houre-glaſſe runne,
But I ſhould thinke of ſhallows, and of ﬂats,
And ſee my wealthy Andrew docks in ſand,
Vailing her high top lower then her ribs
To kiſſe her buriall; ſhould I gœ to Church
And ſee the holy ediﬁce of ſtone,
And not bethinke me ſtraight of dangerous rocks,
Which touching but my gentle Veſſels ſide
Would ſcatter all her ſpices on the ſtreame,
Enrobe the roring waters with my ſilkes,
And in a word, but euen now worth this,
And now worth nothing. Shall I haue the thought
To thinke on this, and ſhall I lacke the thought
That ſuch a thing bechaunc’d would make me ſad!
But tell not me, I know Anthonio
Is ſad to thinke vpon his merchandize.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Beleeue me no, I thanke my fortune for it,
My ventures are not in one bottome truſted,
Nor to one place; nor is my whole eſtate
Vpon the fortune of this preſent yeere:
Therefore my merchandize makes me not ſad.

speech.speaker: Sola.
speech.line: Why then you are in loue.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Fie, ﬁe.

speech.speaker: Sola.
speech.line: Not in loue neither: then let vs ſay you are ſad
Becauſe you are not merry: and ’twere as eaſie
For you to laugh and leape, and ſay you are merry
Becauſe you are not ſad. Now by two-headed Ianus,
Nature hath fram’d ſtrange fellowes in her time:
Some that will euermore peepe through their eyes,
And laugh like Parrats at a bag-piper.
And other of ſuch vineger aſpeƈt,
That they’ll not ſhew their teeth in way of ſmile,
Though Neſtor ſweare the ieſt be laughable.

speech.speaker: Sola.
speech.line: Heere comes Baſſanio,
Your moſt noble Kinſman,
Gratiano, and Lorenſo. Faryewell,
We leaue you now with better company.

speech.speaker: Sala.
speech.line: I would haue ſtaid till I had made you merry,
If worthier friends had not preuented me.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Your worth is very deere in my regard.
I take it your owne buſines calls on you,
And you embrace th’occaſion to depart.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Good morrow my good Lords.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Good ſigniors both, when ſhall we laugh? ſay, when?
You grow exceeding ſtrange: muſt it be ſo?

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Wee’ll make our leyſures to attend on yours.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: My Lord Baſſanio, ſince you haue found Anthonio
We two will leaue you, but at dinner time
I pray you haue in minde where we muſt meete.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: I will not faile you.

speech.speaker: Grat.
speech.line: You looke not well ſignior Anthonio,
You haue too much reſpeƈt vpon the world:
They looſe it that dœ buy it with much care,
Beleeue me you are maruellouſly chang’d.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I hold the world but as the world Gratiano,
A ſtage, where euery man muſt play a part,
And mine a ſad one.

speech.speaker: Grati.
speech.line: Let me play the foole,
With mirth and laughter let old wrinckles come,
And let my Liuer rather heate with wine,
Then my heart coole with mortifying grones.
Why ſhould a man whoſe bloud is warme within,
Sit like his Grandſire, cut in Alablaſter?
Sleepe when he wakes? and creep into the Iaundies
By being peeuiſh? I tell thee what Anthonio,
I loue thee, and it is my loue that ſpeakes:
There are a ſort of men, whoſe viſages
Do creame and mantle like a ſtanding pond,
And do a wilfull ſtilneſſe entertaine,
With purpoſe to be dreſt in an opinion
Of wiſedome, grauity, profound conceit,
As who ſhould ſay, I am ſir an Oracle,
And when I ope my lips, let no dogge barke.
O my Anthonio, I do know of theſe
That therefore onely are reputed wiſe,
For ſaying nothing; when I am verie ſure
If they ſhould ſpeake, would almoſt dam thoſe eares
Which hearing them would call their brothers fooles:
Ile tell thee more of this another time.
But ﬁſh not with this melancholly baite
For this foole Gudgin, this opinion:
Come good Lorenzo, faryewell a while,
Ile end my exhortation aﬅer dinner.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Well, we will leaue you then till dinner time.
I muſt be one of theſe ſame dumbe wiſe men.
For Gratiano neuer let’s me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Well, keepe me company but two yeares mo,
Thou ſhalt not know the ſound of thine owne tongue.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Far you well, Ile grow a talker for this geare.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Thankes ifaith, for ſilence is onely commendable
In a neats tongue dri’d, and a maid not vendible.Exit.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: It is that any thing now.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Gratiano ſpeakes an inﬁnite deale of nothing,
more then any man in all Venice, his reaſons are two
graines of wheate hid in two buſhels of chaffe: you ſhall
ſeeke all day ere you ﬁnde them, & when you haue them
they are not worth the ſearch.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Well: tel me now, what Lady is the ſame
To whom you ſwore a ſecret Pilgrimage
That you to day promis’d to tel me of?

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Tis not vnknowne to you Anthonio
How much I haue diſabled mine eſtate,
By ſomething ſhewing a more ſwelling port
Then my faint meanes would grant continuance:
Nor do I now make mone to be abridg’d
From ſuch a noble rate, but my cheefe care
Is to come fairely off from the great debts
Wherein my time ſomething too prodigall
Hath leﬅ me gag’d: to you Anthonio
I owe the moſt in money, and in loue,
And from your loue I haue a warrantie
To vnburthen all my plots and purpoſes,
How to get cleere of all the debts I owe.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I pray you good Baſſanio let me know it,
And if it ſtand as you your ſelfe ſtill do,
Within the eye of honour, be aſſur’d
My purſe, my perſon, my extreameſt meanes
Lye all vnlock’d to your occaſions.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: In my ſchoole dayes, when I had loſt one ſhaﬅ
I ſhot his fellow of the ſelfeſame ﬂight
The ſelfeſame way, with more aduiſed watch
To ﬁnde the other forth, and by aduenturing both,
I oﬅ found both. I vrge this child-hoode proofe,
Becauſe what followes is pure innocence.
I owe you much, and like a wilfull youth,
That which I owe is loſt: but if you pleaſe
To ſhoote another arrow that ſelfe way
Which you did ſhoot the ﬁrſt, I do not doubt,
As I will watch the ayme: Or to ﬁnde both,
Or bring your latter hazard backe againe,
And thankfully reſt debter for the ﬁrſt.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: You know me well, and herein ſpend but time
To winde about my loue with circumſtance,
And out of doubt you dœ more wrong
In making queſtion of my vttermoſt
Then if you had made waſte of all I haue:
Then dœ but ſay to me what I ſhould dœ
That in your knowledge may by me be done,
And I am preſt vnto it: therefore ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: In Belmont is a Lady richly leﬅ,
And ſhe is faire, and fairer then that word,
Of wondrous vertues, ſometimes from her eyes
I did receiue faire ſpeechleſſe meſſages:
Her name is Portia, nothing vndervallewd
To Cato’s daughter, Brutus Portia,
Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth,
For the four windes blow in from euery coaſt
Renowned ſutors, and her ſunny locks
Hang on her temples like a golden ﬂeece,
Which makes her ſeat of Belmont Cholchos ſtrond,
And many Iaſons come in queſt of her.
O my Anthonio, had I but the meanes
To hold a riuall place with one of them,
I haue a minde preſages me ſuch thriﬅ,
That I ſhould queſtionleſſe be fortunate.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: Thou knowſt that all my fortunes are at ſea,
Neither haue I money, nor commodity
To raiſe a preſent ſumme, therefore gœ forth
Try what my credit can in Venice dœ,
That ſhall be rackt euen to the vttermoſt,
To furniſh thee to Belmont to faire Portia.
Gœ preſently enquire, and ſo will I
Where money is, and I no queſtion make
To haue it of my truſt, or for my ſake.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Portia with her waiting woman Neriſſa.

speech.speaker: Portia.
speech.line: By my troth Nerriſſa, my little body is a wea-
rie of this great world.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: You would be ſweet Madam, if your miſeries
were in the ſame abundance as your good fortunes are:
and yet for ought I ſee, they are as ſicke that ſurfet with
too much, as they that ſtarue with nothing; it is no ſmal
happineſſe therefore to bee ſeated in the meane, ſuper-
ﬂuitie comes ſooner by white haires, but competencie
liues longer.

speech.speaker: Portia.
speech.line: Good ſentences, and well pronounc’d.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: They would be better if well followed.

speech.speaker: Portia.
speech.line: If to dœ were as eaſie as to know what were
good to dœ, Chappels had beene Churches, and poore
mens cottages Princes Pallaces: it is a good Diuine that
followes his owne inſtruƈtions; I can eaſier teach twen-
tie what were good to be done, then be one of the twen-
tie to follow mine owne teaching: the braine may de-
uiſe lawes for the blood, but a hot temper leapes ore a
colde decree, ſuch a hare is madneſſe the youth, to skip
ore the meſhes of good counſaile the cripple; but this
reaſon is not in faſhion to chooſe me a husband: O mee,
the word chooſe, I may neither chooſe whom I would,
nor refuſe whom I diſlike, ſo is the wil of a liuing daugh-
ter curb’d by the will of a dead father: it is not hard Ner-
riſſa, that I cannot chooſe one, nor refuſe none.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Your father was euer vertuous, and holy men
at their death haue good inſpirations, therefore the lot-
terie that hee hath deuiſed in theſe three cheſts of gold,
ſiluer, and leade, whereof who chooſes his meaning,
chooſes you, wil no doubt neuer be choſen by any right-
ly, but one who you ſhall rightly loue: but what warmth
is there in your affeƈtion towards any of theſe Princely
ſuters that are already come?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I pray thee ouer-name them, and as thou nameſt
them, I will deſcribe them, and according to my deſcrip-
tion leuell at my affeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Firſt there is the Neopolitane Prince.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I that’s a colt indeede, for he doth nothing but
talke of his horſe, and hee makes it a great appropria-
tion to his owne good parts that he can ſhoo him him-
ſelfe: I am much afraid my Ladie his mother plaid falſe
with a Smyth.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Than is there the Countie Palentine.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: He doth nothing but frowne (as who ſhould
ſay, and you will not haue me, chooſe: he heares merrie
tales and ſmiles not, I feare hee will proue the weeping
Phyloſopher when he growes old, being ſo full of vn-
mannerly ſadneſſe in his youth.) I had rather to be marri-
ed to a deaths head with a bone in his mouth, then to ei-
ther of theſe: God defend me from theſe two.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: How ſay you by the French Lord, Mounſier
Le Boune?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: God made him, and therefore let him paſſe for a
man, in truth I know it is a ſinne to be a mocker, but he,
why he hath a horſe better then the Neopolitans, a bet-
ter bad habite of frowning then the Count Palentine, he
is euery man in no man, if a Traſſell ſing, he fals ſtraight
a capring, he will fence with his owne ſhadow. If I ſhould
marry him, I ſhould marry twentie husbands: if hee
would deſpiſe me, I would forgiue him, for if he loue me
to madneſſe, I ſhould neuer requite him.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: What ſay you then to Fauconbridge, the yong
Baron of England?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: You know I ſay nothing to him, for hee vnder-
ſtands not me, nor I him: he hath neither Latine, French,
nor Italian, and you will come into the Court & ſweare
that I haue a poore pennie-worth in the Engliſh: hee is a
proper mans piƈture, but alas who can conuerſe with a
dumbe ſhow? how odly he is ſuited, I thinke he bought
his doublet in Italie, his round hoſe in France, his bonnet
in Germanie, and his behauiour euery where.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: What thinke you of the other Lord his neigh-
bour?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: That he hath a neighbourly charitie in him, for
he borrowed a boxe of the eare of the Engliſhman, and
ſwore he would pay him againe when hee was able: I
thinke the Frenchman became his ſuretie, and ſeald vnder
for another.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: How like you the yong Germaine, the Duke of
Saxonies Nephew?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Very vildely in the morning when hee is ſober,
and moſt vildely in the aﬅernoone when hee is drunke:
when he is beſt, he is a little worſe then a man, and when
he is worſt, he is little better then a beaſt: and the worſt
fall that euer fell, I hope I ſhall make ſhiﬅ to go with-
out him.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: If he ſhould offer to chooſe, and chooſe the right
Casket, you ſhould refuſe to performe your Fathers will,
if you ſhould refuſe to accept him.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Therefore for feare of the worſt, I pray thee ſet
a deepe glaſſe of Reiniſh-wine on the contrary Casket,
for if the diuell be within, and that temptation without,
I know he will chooſe it. I will dœ any thing Nerriſſa
ere I will be married to a ſpunge.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: You neede not feare Lady the hauing any of
theſe Lords, they haue acquainted me with their deter-
minations, which is indeede to returne to their home,
and to trouble you with no more ſuite, vnleſſe you may
be won by ſome other ſort then your Fathers impoſiti-
on, depending on the Caskets.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: If I liue to be as olde as Sibilla, I will dye as
chaſte as Diana: vnleſſe I be obtained by the manner
of my Fathers will: I am glad this parcell of woœrs
are ſo reaſonable, for there is not one among them but
I doate on his verie abſence: and I wiſh them a faire de-
parture.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Dœ you not remember Ladie in your Fa-
thers time, a Venecian, a Scholler and a Souldior that
came hither in companie of the Marqueſſe of Mount-
ferrat?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Yes, yes, it was Baſſanio, as I thinke, ſo was hee
call’d.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: True Madam, hee of all the men that euer my
fooliſh eyes look’d vpon, was the beſt deſeruing a faire
Lady.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I remember him well, and I remember him wor-
thy of thy praiſe.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: The four Strangers ſeeke you Madam to take
their leaue: and there is a fore-runner come from a ﬁﬅ,
the Prince of Moroco, who brings word the Prince his
Maiſter will be here to night.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: If I could bid the ﬁﬅ welcome with ſo good
heart as I can bid the other foure farewell, I ſhould be
glad of his approach: if he haue the condition of a Saint,
and the complexion of a diuell, I had rather hee ſhould
ſhriue me then wiue me. Come Nerriſſa, ſirra go before;
whiles wee ſhut the gate vpon one woœr, another
knocks at the doore. Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baſſanio with Shylocke the Iew.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Three thouſand ducates, well.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: I ſir, for three months.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: For three months, well.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: For the which, as I told you,
Anthonio ſhall be bound.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Anthonio ſhall become bound, well.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: May you ſted me? Will you pleaſure me?
Shall I know your anſwere.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Three thouſand ducats for three months,
and Anthonio bound.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Your anſwere to that.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Anthonio is a good man.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Haue you heard any imputation to the con-
trary.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Ho no, no, no, no: my meaning in ſaying he is a
good man, is to haue you vnderſtand me that he is ſufﬁ-
ent, yet his meanes are in ſuppoſition: he hath an Argo-
ſie bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies, I vnder-
ſtand moreouer vpon the Ryalta, he hath a third at Mexi-
co, a fourth for England, and other ventures hee hath
ſquandred abroad, but ſhips are but boords, Saylers but
men, there be land rats, and water rats, water theeues,
and land theeues, I meane Pyrats, and then there is the
perrill of waters, windes, and rocks: the man is notwith-
ſtanding ſufﬁcient, three thouſand ducats, I thinke I may
take his bond.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Be aſſured you may.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I will be aſſured I may: and that I may be aſſu-
red, I will bethinke mee, may I ſpeake with Antho-
nio?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: If it pleaſe you to dine with vs.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Yes, to ſmell porke, to eate of the habitation
which your Prophet the Nazarite coniured the diuell
into: I will buy with you, ſell with you, talke with
you, walke with you, and ſo following: but I will
not eate with you, drinke with you, nor pray with you.
What newes on the Ryalta, who is he comes here?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: This is ſignior Anthonio.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: How like a fawning publican he lookes.
I hate him for he is a Chriſtian:
But more, for that in low ſimplicitie
He lends out money gratis, and brings downe
The rate of vſance here with vs in Venice.
If I can catch him once vpon the hip,
I will feede fat the ancient grudge I beare him.
He hates our ſacred Nation, and he railes
Euen there where Merchants moſt dœ congregate
On me, my bargaines, and my well-worne thriﬅ,
Which he cals interreſt: Curſed by my Trybe
If I forgiue him.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Shylock, dœ you heare.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I am debating of my preſent ſtore,
And by the neere geſſe of my memorie
I cannot inſtantly raiſe vp the groſſe
Of full three thouſand ducats: what of that?
Tuball a wealthy Hebrew of my Tribe
Will furniſh me: but ſoﬅ, how many months
Dœ you deſire? Reſt you faire good ſignior,
Your worſhip was the laſt man in our mouthes.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Shylocke, albeit I neither lend nor borrow
By taking, nor by giuing of exceſſe,
Yet to ſupply the ripe wants of my friend,
Ile breake a cuſtome: is he yet poſſeſt
How much he would?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I, I, three thouſand ducats.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And for three months.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I had forgot, three months, you told me ſo.
Well then, your bond: and let me ſee, but heare you,
Me thoughts you ſaid, you neither lend nor borrow
Vpon aduantage.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I dœ neuer vſe it.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: When Iacob graz’d his Vncle Labans ſheepe,
This Iacob from our holy Abram was
(As his wiſe mother wrought in his behalfe)
The third poſſeſſer; I, he was the third.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And what of him, did he take interreſt?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: No, not take intereſt, not as you would ſay
Direƈtly intereſt, marke what Iacob did,
When Laban and himſelfe were compremyz’d
That all the eanelings which were ſtreakt and pied
Should fall as Iacobs hier, the Ewes being rancke,
In end of Autumne turned to the Rammes,
And when the worke of generation was
Betweene theſe woolly breeders in the aƈt,
The skilfull ſhepheard pil’d me certaine wands,
And in the dooing of the deede of kinde,
He ſtucke them vp before the fulſome Ewes,
Who then conceauing, did in eaning time
Fall party-colour’d lambs, and thoſe were Iacobs.
This was a way to thriue, and he was bleſt:
And thriﬅ is bleſſing if men ſteale it not.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: This was a venture ſir that Iacob ſeru’d for,
A thing not in his power to bring to paſſe,
But ſway’d and faſhion’d by the hand of heauen.
Was this inſerted to make interreſt good?
Or is your gold and ſiluer Ewes and Rams?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I cannot tell, I make it breede as faſt,
But note me ſignior.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Marke you this Baſſanio,
The diuell can cite Scripture for his purpoſe,
An euill ſoule producing holy witneſſe,
Is like a villaine with a ſmiling cheeke,
A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
O what a goodly outſide falſehood hath.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Three thouſand ducats, ’tis a good round ſum.
Three months from twelue, then let me ſee the rate.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well Shylocke, ſhall we be beholding to you?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Signior Anthonio, many a time and oﬅ
In the Ryalto you haue rated me
About my monies and my vſances:
Still haue I borne it with a patient ſhrug,
(For ſuffrance is the badge of all our Tribe.)
You call me miſbeleeuer, cut-throate dog,
And ſpet vpon my Iewiſh gaberdine,
And all for vſe of that which is mine owne.
Well then, it now appeares you neede my helpe:
Gœ to then, you come to me, and you ſay,
Shylocke, we would haue moneyes, you ſay ſo:
You that did voide your rume vpon my beard,
And foote me as you ſpurne a ſtranger curre
Ouer your threſhold, moneyes is your ſuite.
What ſhould I ſay to you? Should I not ſay,
Hath a dog money? Is it poſſible
A curre ſhould lend three thouſand ducats? or
Shall I bend low, and in a bond-mans key
With bated breath, and whiſpring humbleneſſe,
Say this: Faire ſir, you ſpet on me on Wedneſday laſt;
You ſpurn’d me ſuch a day; another time
You cald me dog: and for theſe curteſies
Ile lend you thus much moneyes.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I am as like to call thee ſo againe,
To ſpet on thee againe, to ſpurne thee too.
If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not
As to thy friends, for when did friendſhip take
A breede of barraine mettall of his friend?
But lend it rather to thine enemie,
Who if he breake, thou maiſt with better face
Exaƈt the penalties.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Why looke you how you ſtorme,
I would be friends with you, and haue your loue,
Forget the ſhames that you haue ſtaind me with,
Supplie your preſent wants, and take no doite
Of vſance for my moneyes, and youle not heare me,
This is kinde I offer.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: This were kindneſſe.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: This kindneſſe will I ſhowe,
Gœ with me to a Notarie, ſeale me there
Your ſingle bond, and in a merrie ſport
If you repaie me not on ſuch a day,
In ſuch a place, ſuch ſum or ſums as are
Expreſt in the condition, let the forfeite
Be nominated for an equall pound
Of your faire ﬂeſh, to be cut off and taken
In what part of your bodie it pleaſeth me.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Content infaith, Ile ſeale to ſuch a bond,
And ſay there is much kindneſſe in the Iew.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: You ſhall not ſeale to ſuch a bond for me,
Ile rather dwell in my neceſſitie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why feare not man, I will not forfaite it,
Within theſe two months, that’s a month before
This bond expires, I dœ expeƈt returne
Of thrice three times the valew of this bond.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: O father Abram, what theſe Chriſtians are,
Whoſe owne hard dealings teaches them ſuſpeƈt
The thoughts of others: Praie you tell me this,
If he ſhould breake his daie, what ſhould I gaine
By the exaƈtion of the forfeiture?
A pound of mans ﬂeſh taken from a man,
Is not ſo eſtimable, proﬁtable neither
As ﬂeſh of Muttons, Beefes, or Goates, I ſay
To buy his fauour, I extend this friendſhip,
If he will take it, ſo: if not adiew,
And for my loue I praie you wrong me not.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Yes Shylocke, I will ſeale vnto this bond.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Then meete me forthwith at the Notaries,
Giue him direƈtion for this merrie bond,
And I will gœ and purſe the ducats ſtraite.
See to my houſe leﬅ in the fearefull gard
Of an vnthriﬅie knaue: and preſentlie
Ile be with you.Exit.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Hie thee gentle Iew. This Hebrew will turne
Chriſtian, he growes kinde.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: I like not faire tearmes, and a villaines minde.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come on, in this there can be no diſmaie,
My Shippes come home a month before the daie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Morochus a tawnie Moore all in white, and three or foure followers accordingly, with Portia, Nerriſſa, and their traine. Flo. Cornets.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Miſlike me not for my complexion,
The ſhadowed liuerie of the burniſht ſunne,
To whom I am a neighbour, and neere bred.
Bring me the faireſt creature North-ward borne,
Where Phœbus ﬁre ſcarce thawes the yſicles,
And let vs make inciſion for your loue,
To proue whoſe blood is reddeſt, his or mine.
I tell thee Ladie this aſpeƈt of mine
Hath feard the valiant, (by my loue I ſweare)
The beſt regarded Virgins of our Clyme
Haue lou’d it to: I would not change this hue,
Except to ſteale your thoughts my gentle Queene.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: In tearmes of choiſe I am not ſolie led
By nice direƈtion of a maidens eies:
Beſides, the lottrie of my deſtenie
Bars me the right of voluntarie chooſing:
But if my Father had not ſcanted me,
And hedg’d me by his wit to yeelde my ſelfe
His wife, who wins me by that meanes I told you,
Your ſelfe (renowned Prince) than ſtood as faire
As any commer I haue look’d on yet
For my affeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Euen for that I thanke you,
Therefore I pray you leade me to the Caskets
To trie my fortune: By this Symitare
That ſlew the Sophie, and a Perſian Prince
That won three ﬁelds of Sultan Solyman,
I would ore-ſtare the ſterneſt eies that looke:
Out-braue the heart moſt daring on the earth:
Plucke the yong ſucking Cubs from the ſhe Beare,
Yea, mocke the Lion when he rores for pray
To win the Ladie. But alas, the while
If Hercules and Lychas plaie at dice
Which is the better man, the greater throw
May turne by fortune from the weaker hand:
So is Alcides beaten by his rage,
And ſo may I, blinde fortune leading me
Miſſe that which one vnworthier may attaine,
And die with grieuing.

speech.speaker: Port.
speech.line: You muſt take your chance,
And either not attempt to chooſe at all,
Or ſweare before you chooſe, if you chooſe wrong
Neuer to ſpeake to Ladie aﬅerward
In way of marriage, therefore be aduis’d.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Nor will not, come bring me vnto my chance.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Firſt forward to the temple, aﬅer dinner
Your hazard ſhall be made.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Good fortune then, Cornets.
To make me bleſt or curſed’ſt among men.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Certainely, my conſcience will ſerue me to run
from this Iew my Maiſter: the ﬁend is at mine elbow,
and tempts me, ſaying to me, Iobbe, Launcelet Iobbe, good
Launcelet, or good Iobbe, or good Launcelet Iobbe, vſe
your legs, take the ſtart, run awaie: my conſcience ſaies
no; take heede honeſt Launcelet, take heed honeſt Iobbe,
or as afore-ſaid honeſt Launcelet Iobbe, dœ not runne,
ſcorne running with thy heeles; well, the moſt coragi-
ous ﬁend bids me packe, fia ſaies the ﬁend, away ſaies
the ﬁend, for the heauens rouſe vp a braue minde ſaies
the ﬁend, and run; well, my conſcience hanging about
the necke of my heart, ſaies verie wiſely to me: my ho-
neſt friend Launcelet, being an honeſt mans ſonne, or ra-
ther an honeſt womans ſonne, for indeede my Father did
ſomething ſmack, ſomething grow too; he had a kinde of
taſte; wel, my conſcience ſaies Lancelet bouge not, bouge
ſaies the ﬁend, bouge not ſaies my conſcience, conſcience
ſay I you counſaile well, ﬁend ſay I you counſaile well,
to be rul’d by my conſcience I ſhould ſtay with the Iew
my Maiſter, (who God bleſſe the marke) is a kinde of di-
uell; and to run away from the Iew I ſhould be ruled by
the ﬁend, who ſauing your reuerence is the diuell him-
ſelfe: certainely the Iew is the verie diuell incarnation,
and in my conſcience, my conſcience is a kinde of hard
conſcience, to offer to counſaile me to ſtay with the Iew;
the ﬁend giues the more friendly counſaile: I will runne
ﬁend, my heeles are at your commandement, I will
runne.

scene.stagedir: Enter old Gobbo with a Baſket.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Maiſter yong-man, you I praie you, which is the
waie to Maiſter Iewes?

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: O heauens, this is my true begotten Father, who
being more then ſand-blinde, high grauel blinde, knows
me not, I will trie confuſions with him.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Maiſter yong Gentleman, I praie you which is
the waie to Maiſter Iewes.

speech.speaker: Laun.
speech.line: Turne vpon your right hand at the next tur-
ning, but at the next turning of all on your leﬅ; marrie
at the verie next turning, turne of no hand, but turn down
indireƈtlie to the Iewes houſe.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Be Gods ſonties ’twill be a hard waie to hit, can
you tell me whether one Launcelet that dwels with him
dwell with him or no.

speech.speaker: Laun.
speech.line: Talke you of yong Maſter Launcelet, marke
me now, now will I raiſe the waters; talke you of yong
Maiſter Launcelet?

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: No Maiſter ſir, but a poore mans ſonne, his Fa-
ther though I ſay’t is an honeſt exceeding poore man,
and God be thanked well to liue.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Well, let his Father be what a will, wee talke of
yong Maiſter Launcelet.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Your worſhips friend and Launcelet.

speech.speaker: Laun.
speech.line: But I praie you ergo old man, ergo I beſeech you,
talke you of yong Maiſter Launcelet.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Of Launcelet, ant pleaſe your maiſterſhip.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Ergo Maiſter Lancelet, talke not of maiſter Lance-
let Father, for the yong gentleman according to fates and
deſtinies, and ſuch odde ſayings, the ſiſters three, & ſuch
branches of learning, is indeede deceaſed, or as you
would ſay in plaine tearmes, gone to heauen.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Marrie God forbid, the boy was the verie ſtaffe
of my age, my verie prop.

speech.speaker: Lau.
speech.line: Do I look like a cudgell or a houell-poſt, a ſtaffe
or a prop: dœ you know me Father.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Alacke the day, I know you not yong Gentle-
man, but I praie you tell me, is my boy God reſt his ſoule
aliue or dead.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Dœ you not know me Father.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Alacke ſir I am ſand blinde, I know you not.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Nay, indeede if you had your eies you might
faile of the knowing me: it is a wiſe Father that knowes
his owne childe. Well, old man, I will tell you newes of
your ſon, giue me your bleſſing, truth will come to light,
murder cannot be hid long, a mans ſonne may, but in the
end truth will out.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Praie you ſir ſtand vp, I am ſure you are not
Lancelet my boy.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Praie you let’s haue no more fooling about
it, but giue mee your bleſſing: I am Lancelet your
boy that was, your ſonne that is, your childe that
ſhall be.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: I cannot thinke you are my ſonne.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: I know not what I ſhall thinke of that: but I am
Lancelet the Iewes man, and I am ſure Margerie your wife
is my mother.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Her name is Margerie indeede, Ile be ſworne if
thou be Lancelet, thou art mine owne ﬂeſh and blood:
Lord worſhipt might he be, what a beard haſt thou got;
thou haſt got more haire on thy chin, then Dobbin my
philhorſe has on his taile.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: It ſhould ſeeme then that Dobbins taile
growes backeward. I am ſure he had more haire of his
taile then I haue of my face when I loſt ſaw him.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Lord how art thou chang’d: how dooſt thou
and thy Maſter agree, I haue brought him a preſent; how
gree you now?

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Well, well, but for mine owne part, as I haue ſet
vp my reſt to run awaie, ſo I will not reſt till I haue run
ſome ground; my Maiſter's a verie Iew, giue him a pre-
ſent, giue him a halter, I am famiſht in his ſeruice. You
may tell euerie ﬁnger I haue with my ribs: Father I am
glad you are come, giue me your preſent to one Maiſter
Baſſanio, who indeede giues rare new Liuories, if I ſerue
not him, I will run as far as God has anie ground. O rare
fortune, here comes the man, to him Father, for I am a
Iew if I ſerue the Iew anie longer.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baſſanio with a follower or two.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: You may dœ ſo, but let it be ſo haſted that
ſupper be readie at the fartheſt by ﬁue of the clocke:
ſee theſe Letters deliuered, put the Liueries to mak-
ing, and deſire Gratiano to come anone to my lodg-
ing.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: To him Father.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: God bleſſe your worſhip.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Gramercie, would’ſt thou ought with me.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: Here’s my ſonne ſir, a poore boy.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Not a poore boy ſir, but the rich Iewes man that
would ſir as my Father ſhall ſpeciﬁe.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: He hath a great infeƈtion ſir, as one would ſay
to ſerue.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Indeede the ſhort and the long is, I ſerue the
Iew, and haue a deſire as my Father ſhall ſpeciﬁe.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: His Maiſter and he (sauing your worſhips reue-
rence) are ſcarce catercoſins.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: To be briefe, the verie truth is, that the Iew
hauing done me wrong, doth cauſe me as my Father be-
ing I hope an old man ſhall frutiﬁe vnto you.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: I haue here a diſh of Doues that I would beſtow
vpon your worſhip, and my ſuite is.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: In verie briefe, the ſuite is impertinent to my
ſelfe, as your worſhip ſhall know by this honeſt old man,
and though I ſay it, though old man, yet poore man my
Father.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: One ſpeake for both, what would you?

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Serue you ſir.

speech.speaker: Gob.
speech.line: That is the verie defeƈt of the matter ſir.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: I know thee well, thou haſt obtain’d thy ſuite,
Shylocke thy Maiſter ſpoke with me this daie,
And hath prefer’d thee, if it be preferment
To leaue a rich Iewes ſeruice, to become
The follower of ſo poore a Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: The old prouerbe is verie well parted betweene
my Maiſter Shylocke and you ſir, you haue the grace of
God ſir, and he hath enough.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Thou ſpeak’ſt well; go Father with thy Son,
Take leaue of thy old Maiſter, and enquire
My lodging out, giue him a Liuerie
More garded then his fellowes: ſee it done.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Father in, I cannot get a ſeruice, no, I haue nere
a tongue in my head, well: if anie man in Italie haue a
fairer table which doth offer to ſweare vpon a booke, I
ſhall haue good fortune; gœ too, here’s a ſimple line
of life, here’s a ſmall triﬂe of wiues, alas, ﬁﬅeene wiues
is nothing, a leuen widdowes and nine maides is a ſim-
ple comming in for one man, and then to ſcape drow-
ning thrice, and to be in perill of my life with the edge
of a featherbed, here are ſimple ſcapes: well, if Fortune
be a woman, ſhe’s a good wench for this gere: Father
come, Ile take my leaue of the Iew in the twinkling.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: I praie thee good Leonardo thinke on this,
Theſe things being bought and orderly beſtowed
Returne in haſte, for I dœ feaſt to night
My beſt eſteemd acquaintance, hie thee gœ.

speech.speaker: Leon
speech.line: My beſt endeuors ſhall be done herein.Exit. Le.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Where’s your Maiſter.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Yonder ſir he walkes.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Signior Baſſanio.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Gratiano.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: I haue a ſute to you.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: You haue obtain’d it.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: You muſt not denie me, I muſt gœ with you to
Belmont.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Why then you muſt: but heare thee Gratiano,
Thou art to wilde, to rude, and bold of voyce,
Parts that become thee happily enough,
And in ſuch eyes as ours appeare not faults;
But where they are not knowne, why there they ſhow
Something too liberall, pray thee take paine
To allay with ſome cold drops of modeſtie
Thy skipping ſpirit, leaſt through thy wilde behauiour
I be miſconſterd in the place I gœ to,
And looſe my hopes.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Signor Baſſanio, heare me,
If I dœ not put on a ſober habite,
Talke with reſpeƈt, and ſweare but now and than,
Weare prayer bookes in my pocket, looke demurely,
Nay more, while grace is ſaying hood mine eyes
Thus with my hat, and ſigh and ſay Amen:
Vſe all the obſeruance of ciuillitie
Like one well ſtudied in a ſad oſtent
To pleaſe his Grandam, neuer truſt me more.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Well, we ſhall ſee your bearing.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Nay but I barre to night, you ſhall not gage me
By what we dœ to night.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: No that were pittie,
I would intreate you rather to put on
Your boldeſt ſuite of mirth, for we haue friends
That purpoſe merriment: but far you well,
I haue ſome buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: And I muſt to Lorenſo and the reſt,
But we will viſite you at ſupper time.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: I am ſorry thou wilt leaue my Father ſo,
Our houſe is hell, and thou a merrie diuell
Did’ſt rob it of ſome taſte of tediouſneſſe;
But far thee well, there is a ducat for thee,
And Lancelet, ſoone at ſupper ſhalt thou ſee
Lorenzo, who is thy new Maiſters gueſt,
Giue him this Letter, dœ it ſecretly,
And ſo farewell: I would not haue my Father
ſee me talke with thee.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Adue, teares exhibit my tongue, moſt beautifull
Pagan, moſt ſweete Iew, if a Chriſtian dœ not play the
knaue and get thee, I am much deceiued; but adue, theſe
fooliſh drops dœ ſomewhat drowne my manly ſpirit:
adue.Exit.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Farewell good Lancelet.
Alacke, what hainous ſinne is it in me
To be aſhamed to be my Fathers childe,
But though I am a daughter to his blood,
I am not to his manners: O Lorenzo,
If thou keepe promiſe I ſhall end this ſtrife,
Become a Chriſtian, and thy louing wife.Exit.

scene.stagedir: Enter Gratiano, Lorenzo, Slarino, and Salanio.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Nay, we will ſlinke away in ſupper time,
Diſguiſe vs at my lodging, and returne all in an houre.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: We haue not made good preparation.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: We haue not ſpoke vs yet of Torch-bearers.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: ’Tis vile vnleſſe it may be quaintly ordered,
And better in my minde not vndertooke.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: ’Tis now but foure of clock, we haue two houres
To furniſh vs; friend Lancelet what’s the newes.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: And it ſhall pleaſe you to breake vp this, ſhall it
ſeeme to ſigniﬁe.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I know the hand, in faith ’tis a faire hand
And whiter then the paper it writ on,
Is the faire hand that writ.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Loue newes in faith.

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: By your leaue ſir.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Whither gœſt thou?

speech.speaker: Lan.
speech.line: Marry ſir to bid my old Maſter the Iew to ſup
to night with my new Maſter the Chriſtian.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Hold here, take this, tell gentle Ieſſica
I will not faile her, ſpeake it priuately:
Go Gentlemen, will you prepare you for this Maſke to night,
I am prouided of a Torch-bearer.Exit. Clowne.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: I marry, ile be gone about it ſtrait.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: And ſo will I.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Meete me and Gratiano at Gratianos lodging
Some houre hence.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: ’Tis good we do ſo.Exit.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Was not that Letter from faire Ieſſica?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I muſt needes tell thee all, ſhe hath direƈted
How I ſhall take her from her Fathers houſe,
What gold and iewels ſhe is furniſht with,
What Pages ſuite ſhe hath in readineſſe:
If ere the Iew her Father come to heauen,
It will be for his gentle daughters ſake;
And neuer dare miſfortune croſſe her foote,
Vnleſſe ſhe dœ it vnder this excuſe,
That ſhe is iſſue to a faithleſſe Iew:
Come gœ with me, pervſe this as thou gœſt,
Faire Ieſſica ſhall be my Torch-bearer.Exit.

scene.stagedir: Enter Iew, and his man that was the Clowne.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Well, thou ſhall ſee, thy eyes ſhall be thy iudge,
The difference of old Shylocke and Baſſanio;
What Ieſſica, thou ſhalt not gurmandize
As thou haſt done with me: what Ieſſica?
And ſleepe, and ſnore, and rend apparrell out.
Why Ieſſica I ſay.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why Ieſſica.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Who bids thee call? I do not bid thee call.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Your worſhip was wont to tell me
I could dœ nothing without bidding.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Call you? what is your will?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I am bid forth to ſupper Ieſſica,
There are my Keyes: but wherefore ſhould I go?
I am not bid for loue, they ﬂatter me,
But yet Ile gœ in hate, to feede vpon
The prodigall Chriſtian. Ieſſica my girle,
Looke to my houſe, I am right loath to gœ,
There is ſome ill a bruing towards my reſt,
For I did dreame of money bags to night.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I beſeech you ſir gœ, my yong Maſter
Doth expeƈt your reproach.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: So dœ I his.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: And they haue conſpired together, I will not ſay
you ſhall ſee a Maſke, but if you dœ, then it was not for
nothing that my noſe fell a bleeding on blacke monday
laſt, at ſix a clocke ith morning, falling out that yeere on
aſhwenſday was foure yeere in th’aﬅernoone.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: What are their maskes? heare you me Ieſſica,
Lock vp my doores, and when you heare the drum
And the vile ſquealing of the wry-neckt Fife,
Clamber not you vp to the caſements then,
Nor thruſt your head into the publique ſtreete
To gaze on Chriſtian fooles with varniſht faces:
But ſtop my houſes eares, I meane my caſements,
Let not the ſound of ſhallow fopperie enter
My ſober houſe. By Iacobs ſtaffe I ſweare,
I haue no minde of feaſting forth to night:
But I will gœ: gœ you before me ſirra,
Say I will come.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I will gœ before ſir,
Miſtris looke out at window for all this;
There will come a Chriſtian by,
Will be worth a Iewes eye.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: What ſaies that foole of Hagars off-ſpring?
ha.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: His words were farewell miſtris, nothing elſe.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: The patch is kinde enough, but a huge feeder:
Snaile-ſlow in proﬁt, but he ſleepes by day
More then the wilde-cat: drones hiue not with me,
Therefore I part with him, and part with him
To one that I would haue him helpe to waſte
His borrowed purſe. Well Ieſſica gœ in,
Perhaps I will returne immediately;
Dœ as I bid you, ſhut dores aﬅer you, faſt binde, faſt ﬁnde,
A prouerbe neuer ſtale in thriﬅie minde.Exit.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Farewell, and if my fortune be not croſt,
I haue a Father, you a daughter loſt.Exit.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Maskers, Gratiano and Salino.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: This is the penthouſe vnder which Lorenzo
Deſired vs to make a ſtand.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: His houre is almoſt paſt.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: And it is meruaile he out-dwels his houre,
For louers euer run before the clocke.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: O ten times faſter Venus Pidgions ﬂye
To ſteale loues bonds new made, then they are wont
To keepe obliged faith vnforfaited.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: That euer holds, who riſeth from a feaſt
With that keene appetite that he ſits downe?
Where is the horſe that doth vntread againe
His tedious meaſures with the vnbated ﬁre,
That he did pace them ﬁrſt: all things that are,
Are with more ſpirit chaſed then enioy’d.
How like a yonger or a prodigall
The ſkarfed barke puts from her natiue bay,
Hudg’d and embraced by the ſtrumpet winde:
How like a prodigall doth ſhe returne
With ouer-wither’d ribs and ragged ſailes,
Leane, rent, and begger’d by the ſtrumpet winde?

speech.speaker: Salino.
speech.line: Heere comes Lorenzo, more of this hereaﬅer.

scene.speech: Lor. Sweete friends, your patience for my long abode, _ Not I, but my affaires haue made you wait; When you ſhall pleaſe to play the theeues for wiues Ile watch as long for you then: approach Here dwels my father Iew. Hoa, who’s within?

speech.speaker: Ieſſ.
speech.line: Who are you? tell me for more certainty,
Albeit Ile ſweare that I do know your tongue.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Lorenzo, and thy Loue.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Lorenzo certaine, and my loue indeed,
For who loue I ſo much? and now who knowes
But you Lorenzo, whether I am yours?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Heauen and thy thoughts are witneſſ that thou art.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Heere, catch this casket, it is worth the paines,
I am glad ’tis night, you do not looke on me,
For I am much aſham’d of my exchange:
But loue is blinde, and louers cannot ſee
The pretty follies that themſelues commit,
For if they could, Cupid himſelfe would bluſh
To ſee me thus tranſformed to a boy.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Deſcend, for you muſt be my torch-bearer.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: What, muſt I hold a Candle to my ſhames?
They in themſelues goodſooth are too too light.
Why, ’tis an ofﬁce of diſcouery Loue,
And I ſhould be obſcur’d.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: So you are ſweet,
Euen in the louely garniſh of a boy: but come at once,
For the cloſe night doth play the run-away,
And we are ſtaid for at Baſſanio’s feaſt.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: I will make faſt the doores and guild my ſelfe
With ſome more ducats, and be with you ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Now by my hood, a gentle, and no Iew.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Beſhrew me but I loue her heartily.
For ſhe is wiſe, if I can iudge of her.
And faire ſhe is, if that mine eyes be true,
And true ſhe is, as ſhe hath prou’d her ſelfe:
And therefore like her ſelfe, wiſe, faire, and true,
Shall ſhe be placed in my conſtant ſoule.
What, art thou come? on gentlemen, away,
Our masking mates by this time for vs ſtay.Exit.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Signior Anthonio?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fie, ﬁe, Gratiano, where are all the reſt?
’Tis nine a clocke, our friends all ſtay for you,
No maske to night, the winde is come about,
Baſſanio preſently will gœ aboord,
I haue ſent twenty out to ſeeke for you.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: I am glad on’t, I deſire no more delight
Then to be vnder ſaile, and gone to night.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Portia with Morrocho, and both their traines.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Gœ, draw aſide the curtaines, and diſcouer
The ſeuerall Caskets to this noble Prince:
Now make your choyſe.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: The ﬁrſt of gold, who this inſcription beares,
Who chooſeth me, ſhall gaine what men deſire.
The ſecond ſiluer, which this promiſe carries,
Who chooſeth me, ſhall get as much as he deſerues.
This third, dull lead, with warning all as blunt,
Who chooſeth me, muſt giue and hazard all he hath.
How ſhall I know if I dœ chooſe the right?
How ſhall I know if I dœ chooſe the right.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: The one of them containes my piƈture Prince,
If you chooſe that, then I am yours withall.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Some God direƈt my iudgement, let me ſee,
I will ſuruay the inſcriptions, backe againe:
What ſaies this leaden casket?
Who chooſeth me, muſt giue and hazard all he hath.
Muſt giue, for what? for lead, hazard for lead?
This casket threatens men that hazard all
Dœ it in hope of faire aduantages:
A golden minde ſtoopes not to ſhowes of droſſe,
Ile then nor giue nor hazard ought for lead.
What ſaies the Siluer with her virgin hue?
Who chooſeth me, ſhall get as much as he deſerues.
As much as he deſerues; pauſe there Morocho,
And weigh thy value with an euen hand,
If thou beeſt rated by thy eſtimation
Thou dooſt deſerue enough, and yet enough
May not extend ſo farre as to the Ladie:
And yet to be afeard of my deſeruing,
Were but a weake diſabling of my ſelfe.
As much as I deſerue, why that’s the Lady.
I dœ in birth deſerue her, and in fortunes,
In graces, and in qualities of breeding:
But more then theſe, in loue I dœ deſerue.
What if I ſtrai’d no farther, but choſe here?
Let’s ſee once more this ſaying grau’d in gold.
Who chooſeth me ſhall gaine what many men deſire:
Why that’s the Lady, all the world deſires her:
From the foure corners of the earth they come
To kiſſe this ſhrine, this mortall breathing Saint.
The Hircanion deſerts, and the vaſte wildes
Of wide Arabia are as throughfares now
For Princes to come view faire Portia.
The waterie Kingdome, whoſe ambitious head
Spets in the face of heauen, is no barre
To ſtop the forraine ſpirits, but they come
As ore a brooke to ſee faire Portia.
One of theſe three containes her heauenly piƈture.
Is’t like that Lead containes her? ’twere damnation
To thinke ſo baſe a thought, it were too groſe
To rib her ſearecloath in the obſcure graue:
Or ſhall I thinke in Siluer ſhe’s immur’d
Being ten times vndervalued to tride gold;
O ſinfull thought, neuer ſo rich a Iem
Was ſet in worſe then gold! They haue in England
A coyne that beares the ﬁgure of an Angell
Stampt in gold, but that’s inſculpt vpon:
But here an Angell in a golden bed
Lies all within. Deliuer me the key:
Here dœ I chooſe, and thriue I as I may.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: There take it Prince, and if my forme lye there
Then I am yours.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: O hell! what haue we here, a carrion death,
Within whoſe emptie eye there is a written ſcroule;
Ile reade the writing.

line.italic: All that gliſters is not gold,
Oﬅen haue you heard that told;
Many a man his life hath ſold
But my outſide to behold;
Guilded timber dœ wormes infold:
Had you beene as wiſe as bold,
Yong in limbs, in iudgement old,
Your anſwere had not beene inſcrold,
Fareyouwell, your ſuite is cold,

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Cold indeede, and labour loſt,
Then farewell heate, and welcome froſt:
Portia adew, I haue too grieu’d a heart
To take a tedious leaue: thus looſers part.Exit.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: A gentle riddance: draw the curtaines, go:
Let all of his complexion chooſe me ſo.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Why man I ſaw Baſſanio vnder ſayle;
With him is Gratiano gone along;
And in their ſhip I am ſure Lorenzo is not.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: The villaine Iew with outcries raiſd the Duke.
Who went with him to ſearch Baſſanios ſhip.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: He comes too late, the ſhip was vnderſaile;
But there the Duke was giuen to vnderſtand
That in a Gondilo were ſeene together
Lorenzo and his amorous Ieſſica.
Beſides, Anthonio certiﬁed the Duke
They were not with Baſſanio in his ſhip.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: I neuer heard a paſſion ſo confuſd,
So ſtrange, outragious, and ſo variable,
As the dogge Iew did vtter in the ſtreets;
My daughter, O my ducats, O my daughter,
Fled with a Chriſtian, O my Chriſtian ducats!
Iuſtice, the law, my ducats, and my daughter;
A ſealed bag, two ſealed bags of ducats,
Of double ducats, ſtolne from me by my daughter,
And iewels, two ſtones, two rich and precious ſtones,
Stolne by my daughter: iuſtice, ﬁnde the girle,
She hath the ſtones vpon her, and the ducats.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Why all the boyes in Venice follow him,
Crying his ſtones, his daughter, and his ducats.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Let good Anthonio looke he keepe his day
Or he ſhall pay for this.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Marry well remembred,
I reaſon’d with a Frenchman yeſterday,
Who told me, in the narrow ſeas that part
The French and Engliſh, there miſcaried
A veſſell of our countrey richly fraught:
I thought vpon Anthonio when he told me,
And wiſht in ſilence that it were not his.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: You were beſt to tell Anthonio what you heare.
Yet dœ not ſuddainely, for it may grieue him.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: A kinder Gentleman treads not the earth,
I ſaw Baſſanio and Anthonio part,
Baſſanio told him he would make ſome ſpeede
Of his returne: he anſwered, dœ not ſo,
Slubber not buſineſſe for my ſake Baſſanio,
But ſtay the very riping of the time,
And for the Iewes bond which he hath of me,
Let it not enter in your minde of loue:
Be merry, and imploy your chiefeſt thoughts
To courtſhip, and ſuch faire oſtents of loue
As ſhall conueniently become you there;
And euen there his eye being big with teares,
Turning his face, he put his hand behinde him,
And with affeƈtion wondrous ſencible
He wrung Baſſanios hand, and ſo they parted.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: I thinke he onely loues the world for him,
I pray thee let vs gœ and ﬁnde him out
And quicken his embraced heauineſſe
With ſome delight or other.

speech.speaker: Sal
speech.line: Dœ we ſo.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Quick, quick I pray thee, draw the curtain ſtrait,
The Prince of Arragon hath tane his oath,
And comes to his eleƈtion preſently.

scene.stagedir: Enter Arragon, his traine, and Portia. Flor. Cornets.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Behold, there ſtand the caskets noble Prince,
If you chooſe that wherein I am contain’d,
Straight ſhall our nuptiall rights be ſolemniz’d:
But if thou faile, without more ſpeech my Lord,
You muſt be gone from hence immediately.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: I am enioynd by oath to obſerue three things;
Firſt, neuer to vnfold to any one
Which casket ’twas I choſe; next, if I faile
Of the right casket, neuer in my life
To woœ a maide in way of marriage:
Laſtly, if I dœ faile in fortune of my choyſe,
Immediately to leaue you, and be gone.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: To theſe iniunƈtions euery one doth ſweare
That comes to hazard for my worthleſſe ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: And ſo haue I addreſt me, fortune now
To my hearts hope: gold, ſiluer, and baſe lead.
Who chooſeth me muſt giue and hazard all he hath.
You ſhall looke fairer ere I giue or hazard.
What ſaies the golden cheſt, ha, let me ſee.
Who chooſeth me, ſhall gaine what many men deſire:
What many men deſire, that many may be meant
By the foole multitude that chooſe by ſhow,
Not learning more then the fond eye doth teach,
Which pries not to th’interior, but like the Martlet
Builds in the weather on the outward wall,
Euen in the force and rode of caſualtie.
I will not chooſe what many men deſire,
Becauſe I will not iumpe with common ſpirits,
And ranke me with the barbarous multitudes.
Why then to thee thou Siluer treaſure houſe,
Tell me once more, what title thou dooſt beare;
Who chooſeth me ſhall get as much as he deſerues:
And well ſaid too; for who ſhall gœ about
To coſen Fortune, and be honourable
Without the ſtampe of merrit, let none preſume
To weare an vndeſerued dignitie:
O that eſtates, degrees, and ofﬁces,
Were not deriu’d corruptly, and that cleare honour
Were purchaſt by the merrit of the wearer;
How many then ſhould couer that ſtand bare?
How many be commanded that command?
How much low pleaſantry would then be gleaned
From the true ſeede of honor? And how much honor
Pickt from the chaffe and ruine of the times,
To be new varniſht: Well, but to my choiſe.
Who chooſeth me ſhall get as much as he deſerues.
I will aſſume deſert; giue me a key for this,
And inſtantly vnlocke my fortunes here.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Too long a pauſe for that which you ﬁnde there.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: What’s here, the portrait of a blinking idiot
Preſenting me a ſcedule, I will reade it:
How much vnlike art thou to Portia?
How much vnlike my hopes and my deſeruings?
Who chooſeth me, ſhall haue as much as he deſerues.
Did I deſerue no more then a fooles head,
Is that my prize, are my deſerts no better?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: To offend and iudge are diſtinƈt ofﬁces,
And of oppoſed natures.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: What is here?

line.italic: The ﬁer ſeauen times tried this,
Seauen times tried that iudgement is,
That did neuer chooſe amis,
Some there be that ſhadowes kiſſe,
Such haue but a ſhadowes bliſſe:
There be fooles aliue Iwis
Siluer’d o’re, and ſo was this:
Take what wife you will to bed,
I will euer be your head:
So be gone, you are ſped.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: Still more foole I ſhall appeare
By the time I linger here,
With one fooles head I came to woo,
But I gœ away with two.
Sweet adue, Ile keepe my oath,
Patiently to beare my wroath.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Thus hath the candle ſing’d the moath:
O theſe deliberate fooles when they dœ chooſe,
They haue the wiſdome by their wit to looſe.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: The ancient ſaying is no hereſie,
Hanging and wiuing gœs by deſtinie.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Come draw the curtaine Nerriſſa.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Where is my Lady?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Here, what would my Lord?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Madam, there is a-lighted at your gate
A yong Venetian, one that comes before
To ſigniﬁe th’approaching of his Lord,
From whom he bringeth ſenſible regreets;
To wit (beſides commends and curteous breath)
Giﬅs of rich value; yet I haue not ſeene
So likely an Embaſſador of loue.
A day in Aprill neuer came ſo ſweete
To ſhow how coſtly Sommer was at hand,
As this fore-ſpurrer comes before his Lord.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: No more I pray thee, I am halfe a-feard
Thou wilt ſay anone he is ſome kin to thee,
Thou ſpend’ſt ſuch high-day wit in praiſing him:
Come, come Nerryſſa, for I long to ſee
Quicke Cupids Poſt, that comes ſo mannerly.

speech.speaker: Ner
speech.line: Baſſanio Lord, loue if thy will it be.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Now, what newes on the Ryalto?

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Why yet it liues there vncheckt, that Anthonio
hath a ſhip of rich lading wrackt on the narrow Seas; the
Goodwins I thinke they call the place, a very dangerous
ﬂat, and fatall, where the carcaſſes of many a tall ſhip, lye
buried, as they ſay, if my goſſips report be an honeſt wo-
man of her word.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: I would ſhe were as lying a goſſip in that, as euer
knapt Ginger, or made her neighbours beleeue ſhe wept
for the death of a third husband: but it is true, without
any ſlips of prolixity, or croſſing the plaine high-way of
talke, that the good Anthonio, the honeſt Anthonio; ō that
I had a title good enough to keepe his name company!

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Come, the full ſtop.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Ha, what ſayeſt thou, why the end is, he hath loſt
a ſhip.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: I would it might proue the end of his loſſes.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Let me ſay Amen betimes, leaſt the diuell croſſe
my praier, for here he comes in the likenes of a Iew. How
now Shylocke, what newes among the Merchants?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: You knew none ſo well, none ſo well as you, of
my daughters ﬂight.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: That’s certaine, I for my part knew the Tailor
that made the wings ſhe ﬂew withall.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: And Shylocke for his owne part knew the bird was
ﬂedg’d, and then it is the complexion of them al to leaue
the dam.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: She is damn’d for it.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: That’s certaine, if the diuell may be her Iudge.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: My owne ﬂeſh and blood to rebell.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Out vpon it old carrion, rebels it at theſe yeeres.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I ſay my daughter is my ﬂeſh and bloud.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: There is more difference betweene thy ﬂeſh and
hers, then betweene Iet and Iuorie, more betweene your
bloods, then there is betweene red wine and renniſh: but
tell vs, dœ you heare whether Anthonio haue had anie
loſſe at ſea or no?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: There I haue another bad match, a bankrout, a
prodigall, who dare ſcarce ſhew his head on the Ryalto,
a begger that was vſd to come ſo ſmug vpon the Mart:
let him look to his bond, he was wont to call me Vſurer,
let him looke to his bond, he was wont to lend money
for a Chriſtian curtſie, let him looke to his bond.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Why I am ſure if he forfaite, thou wilt not take
his ﬂeſh, what’s that good for?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: To baite ﬁſh withall, if it will feede nothing
elſe, it will feede my reuenge; he hath diſgrac’d me, and
hindred me halfe a million, laught at my loſſes, mockt at
my gaines, ſcorned my Nation, thwarted my bargaines,
cooled my friends, heated mine enemies, and what’s the
reaſon? I am a Iewe: Hath not a Iew eyes? hath not a
Iew hands, organs, dementions, ſences, affeƈtions, paſſi-
ons, fed with the ſame foode, hurt with the ſame wea-
pons, ſubieƈt to the ſame diſeaſes, healed by the ſame
meanes, warmed and cooled by the ſame Winter and
Sommmer as a Chriſtian is: if you pricke vs dœ we not
bleede? if you tickle vs, dœ we not laugh? if you poiſon
vs dœ we not die? and if you wrong vs ſhall we not re-
uenge? if we are like you in the reſt, we will reſemble you
in that. If a Iew wrong a Chriſtian, what is his humility,
reuenge? If a Chriſtian wrong a Iew, what ſhould his ſuf-
ferance be by Chriſtian example, why reuenge? The vil-
lanie you teach me I will execute, and it ſhall gœ hard
but I will better the inſtruƈtion.

scene.line: Gentlemen, my maiſter Anthonio is at his houſe, and
deſires to ſpeake with you both.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: We haue beene vp and downe to ſeeke him.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: Here comes another of the Tribe, a third cannot
be matcht, vnleſſe the diuell himſelfe turne Iew.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: How now Tuball, what newes from Genowa? haſt
thou found my daughter?

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: I oﬅen came where I did heare of ſter, but can-
not ﬁnde her.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Why there, there, there, there, a diamond gone
coſt me two thouſand ducats in Franckford, the curſe ne-
uer fell vpon our Nation till now, I neuer felt it till now,
two thouſand ducats in that, and other precious, preci-
ous iewels: I would my daughter were dead at my foot,
and the iewels in her eare: would ſhe were hearſt at my
foote, and the duckets in her cofﬁn: no newes of them,
why ſo? and I know not how much is ſpent in the ſearch:
why thou loſſe vpon loſſe, the theefe gone with ſo
much, and ſo much to ﬁnde the theefe, and no ſatisfa-
ƈtion, no reuenge, nor no ill luck ſtirring but what lights
a my ſhoulders, no ſighes but a my breathing, no teares
but a my ſhedding.

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: Yes, other men haue ill lucke too, Anthonio as
I heard in Genowa?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: What, what, what, ill lucke, ill lucke.

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: Hath an Argoſie caſt away comming from Tri-
polis.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I thanke God, I thanke God, is it true, is it true?

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: I ſpoke with ſome of the Saylers that eſcaped
the wracke.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I thanke thee good Tuball, good newes, good
newes: ha, ha, here in Genowa.

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: Your daughter ſpent in Genowa, as I heard, one
night foureſcore ducats.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Thou ſtick’ſt a dagger in me, I ſhall neuer ſee my
gold againe, foureſcore ducats at a ſitting, foureſcore du-
cats.

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: There came diuers of Anthonios creditors in my
company to Venice, that ſweare hee cannot chooſe but
breake.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I am very glad of it, ile plague him, ile torture
him, I am glad of it,

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: One of them ſhewed me a ring that hee had of
your daughter for a Monkie.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Out vpon her, thou tortureſt me Tuball, it was
my Turkies, I had it of Leah when I was a Batcheler: I
would not haue giuen it for a wilderneſſe of Monkies.

speech.speaker: Tub.
speech.line: But Anthonio is certainely vndone.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Nay, that’s true, that’s very true, gœ Tuball, ſee
me an Ofﬁcer, beſpeake him a fortnight before, I will
haue the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Ve-
nice, I can make what merchandize I will: gœ Tuball,
and meete me at our Sinagogue, gœ good Tuball, at our
Sinagogue Tuball. Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baſſanio, Portia, Gratiano, and all their traine.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I pray you tarrie, pauſe a day or two
Before you hazard, for in chooſing wrong
I looſe your companie; therefore forbeare a while,
There’s ſomething tels me (but it is not loue)
I would not looſe you, and you know your ſelfe,
Hate counſailes not in ſuch a quallitie;
But leaſt you ſhould not vnderſtand me well,
And yet a maiden hath no tongue, but thought,
I would detaine you here ſome month or two
Before you venture for me. I could teach you
How to chooſe right, but then I am forſworne,
So will I neuer be, ſo may you miſſe me,
But if you dœ, youle make me wiſh a ſinne,
That I had beene forſworne: Beſhrow your eyes,
They haue ore-lookt me and deuided me,
One halfe of me is yours, the other halfe yours,
Mine owne I would ſay: but of mine then yours,
And ſo all yours; O theſe naughtie times
Puts bars betweene the owners and their rights.
And ſo though yours, not yours (proue it ſo)
Let Fortune gœ to hell for it, not I.
I ſpeake too long, but ’tis to peize the time,
To ich it, and to draw it out in length,
To ſtay you from eleƈtion.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Let me chooſe,
For as I am, I liue vpon the racke.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Vpon the racke Baſſanio, then confeſſe
What treaſon there is mingled with your loue.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: None but that vglie treaſon of miſtrust.
Which makes me feare the enioying of my loue:
There may as well be amitie and life,
’Tweene ſnow and ﬁre, as treaſon and my loue.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I, but I feare you ſpeake vpon the racke,
Where men enforced doth ſpeake any thing.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Promiſe me life, and ile confeſſe the truth.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Well then, confeſſe and liue.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Confeſſe and loue
Had beene the verie ſum of my confeſſion:
O happie torment, when my torturer
Doth teach me anſwers for deliuerance:
But let me to my fortune and the caskets.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Away then, I am lockt in one of them,
If you dœ loue me, you will ﬁnde me out.
Nerryſſa and the reſt, ſtand all aloofe,
Let muſicke ſound while he doth make his choiſe,
Then if he looſe he makes a Swan-like end,
Fading in muſique. That the compariſon
May ſtand more proper, my eye ſhall be the ſtreame
And watrie death-bed for him: he may win,
And what is muſique than? Than muſique is
Euen as the ﬂouriſh, when true ſubieƈts bowe
To a new crowned Monarch: Such it is,
As are thoſe dulcet ſounds in breake of day,
That creepe into the dreaming bride-groomes eare,
And ſummon him to marriage. Now he gœs
With no leſſe preſence, but with much more loue
Then yong Alcides, when he did redeeme
The virgine tribute, paied by howling Troy
To the Sea-monſter: I ſtand for ſacriﬁce,
The reſt aloofe are the Dardanian wiues:
With bleared viſages come forth to view
The iſſue of th’exploit: Gœ Hercules,
Liue thou, I liue with much more diſmay
I view the ſight, then thou that mak’ſt the fray.
speech.stagedir: A Song the whilſt Baſſanio comments on the Caskets to himſelfe
speech.line: Tell me where is fancie bred,
Or in the heart, or in the head:
How begot, how nouriſhed. Replie, replie.
It is engendred in the eyes,
With gazing fed, and Fancie dies,
In the cradle where it lies:
Let vs all ring Fancies knell.
Ile begin it.
Ding, dong, bell.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Ding, dong, bell.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: So may the outward ſhowes be leaſt themſelues
The world is ſtill deceiu’d with ornament.
In Law, what Plea ſo tainted and corrupt,
But being ſeaſon’d with a gracious voice,
Obſcures the ſhow of euill? In Religion,
What damned error, but ſome ſober brow
Will bleſſe it, and approue it with a text,
Hiding the groſeneſſe with faire ornament:
There is no voice ſo ſimple, but aſſumes
Some marke of vertue on his outward parts;
How manie cowards, whoſe hearts are all as falſe
As ſtayers of ſand, weare yet vpon their chins
The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars,
Who inward ſearcht, haue lyuers white as milke,
And theſe aſſume but valors excrement,
To render them redoubted. Looke on beautie,
And you ſhall ſee ’tis purchaſt by the weight,
Which therein workes a miracle in nature,
Making them lighteſt that weare moſt of it:
So are thoſe criſped ſnakie golden locks
Which makes ſuch wanton gambols with the winde
Vpon ſuppoſed faireneſſe, oﬅen knowne
To be the dowrie of a ſecond head,
The ſcull that bred them in the Sepulcher.
Thus ornament is but the guiled ſhore
To a moſt dangerous ſea: the beautious ſcarfe
Vailing an Indian beautie; In a word,
The ſeeming truth which cunning times put on
To intrap the wiſeſt. Therefore then thou gaudie gold,
Hard food for Midas, I will none of thee,
Nor none of thee thou pale and common drudge
’Tweene man and man: but thou, thou meager lead
Which rather threatneſt then doſt promiſe ought,
Thy paleneſſe moues me more then eloquence,
And here chooſe I, ioy be the conſequence.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: How all the other paſſions ﬂeet to ayre,
As doubtfull thoughts, and raſh imbrac’d deſpaire:
And ſhuddring feare, and greene-eyed iealouſie.
O loue be moderate, allay thy extaſie,
In meaſure raine thy ioy, ſcant this exceſſe,
I feele too much thy bleſſing, make it leſſe,
For feare I ſurfeit.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: What ﬁnde I here?
Faire Portias counterfeit. What demie God
Hath come ſo neere creation? moue theſe eies?
Or whether riding on the bals of mine
Seeme they in motion? Here are ſeuer’d lips
Parted with ſuger breath, ſo ſweet a barre
Should ſunder ſuch ſweet friends: here in her haires
The Painter plaies the Spider, and hath wouen
A golden meſh t’intrap the hearts of men
Faſter then gnats in cobwebs: but her eies,
How could he ſee to dœ them? hauing made one,
Me thinkes it ſhould haue power to ſteale both his
And leaue it ſelfe vnfurniſht: Yet looke how farre
The ſubſtance of my praiſe doth wrong this ſhadow
In vnderpriſing it, ſo farre this ſhadow
Doth limpe behinde the ſubſtance. Here’s the ſcroule,
The continent, and ſummarie of my fortune.

line.italic: You that chooſe not by the view
Chance as faire, and chooſe as true:
Since this fortune fals to you,
Be content, and ſeeke no new.
If you be well pleaſd with this,
And hold your fortune for your bliſſe,
Turne you where your Lady is,
And claime her with a louing kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: A gentle ſcroule: Faire Lady, by your leaue,
I come by note to giue, and to receiue,
Like one of two contending in a prize
That thinks he hath done well in peoples eies:
Hearing applauſe and vniuerſall ſhout,
Giddie in ſpirit, ſtill gazing in a doubt
Whether thoſe peales of praiſe be his or no.
So thrice faire Lady ſtand I euen ſo,
As doubtfull whether what I ſee be true,
Vntill conﬁrm’d, ſign’d, ratiﬁed by you.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: You ſee my Lord Baſſiano where I ſtand,
Such as I am; though for my ſelfe alone
I would not be ambitious in my wiſh,
To wiſh my ſelfe much better, yet for you,
I would be trebled twenty times my ſelfe,
A thouſand times more faire, ten thouſand times
More rich, that onely to ſtand high in your account,
I might in vertues, beauties, liuings, friends,
Exceed account: but the full ſumme of me
Is ſum of nothing: which to terme in groſſe,
Is an vnleſſoned girle, vnſchool’d, vnpraƈtiz’d,
Happy in this, ſhe is not yet ſo old
But ſhe may learne: happier then this,
Shee is not bred ſo dull but ſhe can learne;
Happieſt of all, is that her gentle ſpirit
Commits it ſelfe to yours to be direƈted,
As from her Lord, her Gouernour, her King.
My ſelfe, and what is mine, to you and yours
Is now conuerted. But now I was the Lord
Of this faire manſion, maſter of my ſeruants,
Queene ore my ſelfe: and euen now, but now,
This houſe, theſe ſeruants, and this ſame my ſelfe
Are yours, my Lord, I giue them with this ring,
Which when you part from, looſe, or giue away,
Let it preſage the ruine of your loue,
And be my vantage to exclaime on you.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Maddam, you haue bereﬅ me of all words,
Onely my bloud ſpeakes to you in my vaines,
And there is ſuch confuſion in my powers,
As aﬅer ſome oration fairely ſpoke
By a beloued Prince, there doth appeare
Among the buzzing pleaſed multitude,
Where euery ſomething being blent together,
Turnes to a wilde of nothing, ſaue of ioy
Expreſt, and not expreſt: but when this ring
Parts from this ﬁnger, then parts life from hence,
O then be bold to ſay Baſſanio's dead.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: My Lord and Lady, it is now our time
That haue ſtood by and ſeene our wiſhes proſper,
To cry good ioy, good ioy my Lord and Lady.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: My Lord Baſſanio, and my gentle Lady,
I wiſh you all the ioy that you can wiſh:
For I am ſure you can wiſh none from me:
And when your Honours meane to ſolemnize
The bargaine of your faith: I dœ beſeech you
Euen at that time I may be married too.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: With all my heart, ſo thou canſt get a wife.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: I thanke your Lordſhip, you haue got me one.
My eyes my Lord can looke as ſwiﬅ as yours:
You ſaw the miſtres, I beheld the maid:
You lou’d, I lou’d for intermiſſion,
No more pertaines to me my Lord then you;
Your fortune ſtood vpon the caskets there,
And ſo did mine too, as the matter falls:
For wooing heere vntill I ſwet againe,
And ſwearing till my very rough was dry
With oathes of loue, at laſt, if promiſe laſt,
I got a promiſe of this faire one heere
To haue her loue: prouided that your fortune
Atchieu’d her miſtreſſe.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Is this true Nerriſſa?

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Madam it is ſo, ſo you ſtand pleas’d withall.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: And dœ you Gratiano meane good faith?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Yes faith my Lord.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Our feaſt ſhall be much honored in your mar-
riage.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Weele play with them the ﬁrſt boy for a thou-
ſand ducats.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: What and ſtake downe?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: No, we ſhal nere win at that ſport, and ſtake downe.
But who comes heere? Lorenzo and his Inﬁdell?
What and my old Venetian friend Salerio?

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hether,
If that the youth of my new intereſt heere
Haue power to bid you welcome: by your leaue
I bid my verie friends and Countrimen
Sweet Portia welcome.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: So do I my Lord, they are intirely welcome.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I thanke your honor; for my part my Lord,
My purpoſe was not to haue ſeene you heere,
But meeting with Salerio by the way,
He did intreate mee paſt all ſaying nay
To come with him along.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: I did my Lord,
And I haue reaſon for it, Signior Anthonio
Commends him to you.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Ere I ope his Letter
I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Not ſicke my Lord, vnleſſe it be in minde,
Nor wel, vnleſſe in minde: his Letter there
Wil ſhew you his eſtate.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Nerriſſa, cheere yond ſtranger, bid her welcom.
Your hand Salerio, what’s the newes from Venice?
How doth that royal Merchant good Anthonio;
I know he vvil be glad of our ſucceſſe,
We are the Iaſons, we haue won the ﬂeece.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: I would you had won the ﬂeece that hee hath
loſt.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: There are ſome ſhrewd contents in yond ſame
Paper,
That ſteales the colour from Baſſianos cheeke,
Some deere friend dead, elſe nothing in the world
Could turne ſo much the conſtitution
Of any conſtant man. What, worſe and worſe?
With leaue Baſſanio I am halfe your ſelfe,
And I muſt freely haue the halfe of any thing
That this ſame paper brings you.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: O ſweet Portia,
Heere are a few of the vnpleaſant’ſt words
That euer blotted paper. Gentle Ladie
When I did ﬁrſt impart my loue to you,
I freely told you all the wealth I had
Ran in my vaines: I was a Gentleman,
And then I told you true: and yet deere Ladie,
Rating my ſelfe at nothing, you ſhall ſee
How much I was a Braggart, when I told you
My ſtate was nothing, I ſhould then haue told you
That I was worſe then nothing: for indeede
I haue ingag’d my ſelfe to a deere friend,
Ingag’d my friend to his meere enemie
To feede my meanes. Heere is a Letter Ladie,
The paper as the bodie of my friend,
And euerie word in it a gaping wound
Iſſuing life blood. But is it true Salerio,
Hath all his ventures faild, what not one hit,
From Tripolis, from Mexico and England,
From Lisbon, Barbary, and India,
And not one veſſell ſcape the dreadfull touch
Of Merchant-marring rocks?

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Not one my Lord.
Beſides, it ſhould appeare, that if he had
The preſent money to diſcharge the Iew,
He would not take it: neuer did I know
A creature that did beare the ſhape of man
So keene and greedy to confound a man.
He plyes the Duke at morning and at night,
And doth impeach the freedome of the ſtate
If they deny him iuſtice. Twenty Merchants,
The Duke himſelfe, and the Magniﬁcœs
Of greateſt port haue all perſwaded with him,
But none can driue him from the enuious plea
Of forfeiture, of iuſtice, and his bond.

speech.speaker: Ieſſi.
speech.line: When I was with him, I haue heard him ſweare
To Tuball and to Chus, his Countri-men,
That he would rather haue Anthonio’s ﬂeſh,
Then twenty times the value of the ſumme
That he did owe him: and I know my Lord,
If law, authoritie, and power denie not,
It will gœ hard with poore Anthonio.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Is it your deere friend that is thus in trouble?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: The deereſt friend to me, the kindeſt man,
