The beſt condition’d, and vnwearied ſpirit
In doing curteſies: and one in whom
The ancient Romane honour more appeares
Then any that drawes breath in Italie.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: What ſumme owes he the Iew?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: For me three thouſand ducats.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: What, no more?
Pay him ſixe thouſand, and deface the bond:
Double ſixe thouſand, and then treble that,
Before a friend of this deſcription
Shall loſe a haire through Baſſanio’s fault.
Firſt gœ with me to Church, and call me wife,
And then away to Venice to your friend:
For neuer ſhall you lie by Portias ſide
With an vnquiet ſoule. You ſhall haue gold
To pay the petty debt twenty times ouer.
When it is payd, bring your true friend along,
My maid Nerriſſa, and my ſelfe meane time
Will liue as maids and widdowes; come away,
For you ſhall hence vpon your wedding day:
Bid your friends welcome, ſhow a merry cheere,
Since you are deere bought, I will loue you deere.
But let me heare the letter of your friend.

line.italic: Sweet Baſſanio, my ſhips haue all miſcarried, my Credi-
tors grow cruell, my eſtate is very low, my bond to the Iew is
forfeit, and ſince in paying it, it is impoſſible I ſhould liue, all
debts are cleerd between you and I, if I might ſee you at my
death: notwithſtanding, vſe your pleaſure, if your loue dœ not
perſwade you to come, let not my letter.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: O loue! diſpach all buſines and be gone.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Since I haue your good leaue to gœ away,
I will make haſt; but till I come againe,
No bed ſhall ere be guilty of my ſtay,
Nor reſt be interpoſer twixt vs twaine. Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Iew, and Solanio, and Anthonio, and the Iaylor.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Iaylor, looke to him, tell not me of mercy,
This is the foole that lends out money gratis.
Iaylor, looke to him.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Heare me yet good Shylok.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Ile haue my bond, ſpeake not againſt my bond,
I haue ſworne an oath that I will haue my bond:
Thou call’dſt me dog before thou hadſt a cauſe,
But ſince I am a dog, beware my phangs,
The Duke ſhall grant me iuſtice, I do wonder
Thou naughty Iaylor, that thou art ſo fond
To come abroad with him at his requeſt.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I pray thee heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Ile haue my bond, I will not heare thee ſpeake,
Ile haue my bond, and therefore ſpeake no more,
Ile not be made a ſoﬅ and dull ey’d foole,
To ſhake the head, relent, and ſigh, and yeeld
To Chriſtian interceſſors: follow not,
Ile haue no ſpeaking, I will haue my bond.Exit Iew.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: It is the moſt impenetrable curre
That euer kept with men.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Let him alone,
Ile follow him no more with bootleſſe prayers:
He ſeekes my life, his reaſon well I know;
I oﬅ deliuer’d from his forfeitures
Many that haue at times made mone to me,
Therefore he hates me.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: I am ſure the Duke will neuer grant
this forfeiture to hold.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: The Duke cannot deny the courſe of law:
For the commoditie that ſtrangers haue
With vs in Venice, if it be denied,
Will much impeach the iuſtice of the State,
Since that the trade and proﬁt of the citty
Conſiſteth of all Nations. Therefore gœ,
Theſe greefes and loſſes haue ſo bated mee,
That I ſhall hardly ſpare a pound of ﬂeſh
To morrow, to my bloudy Creditor.
Well Iaylor, on, pray God Baſſanio come
To ſee me pay his debt, and then I care not.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Portia, Nerriſſa, Lorenzo, Ieſſica, and a man of Portias.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Madam, although I ſpeake it in your preſence,
You haue a noble and a true conceit
Of god-like amity, which appeares moſt ſtrongly
In bearing thus the abſence of your Lord.
But if you knew to whom you ſhew this honour,
How true a Gentleman you ſend releefe,
How deere a louer of my Lord your husband,
I know you would be prouder of the worke
Then cuſtomary bounty can enforce you.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I neuer did repent for doing good,
Nor ſhall not now: for in companions
That do conuerſe and waſte the time together,
Whoſe ſoules dœ beare an egal yoke of loue.
There muſt be needs a like proportion
Of lyniaments, of manners, and of ſpirit;
Which makes me thinke that this Anthonio
Being the boſome louer of my Lord,
Muſt needs be like my Lord. If it be ſo,
How little is the coſt I haue beſtowed
In purchaſing the ſemblance of my ſoule;
From out the ſtate of helliſh cruelty,
This comes too neere the praiſing of my ſelfe,
Therefore no more of it: heere other things
Lorenſo I commit into your hands,
The husbandry and mannage of my houſe,
Vntill my Lords returne; for mine owne part
I haue toward heauen breath’d a ſecret vow,
To liue in prayer and contemplation,
Onely attended by Nerriſſa heere,
Vntill her husband and my Lords returne:
There is a monaſtery too miles off,
And there we will abide. I dœ deſire you
Not to denie this impoſition,
The which my loue and ſome neceſſity
Now layes vpon you.

speech.speaker: Lorenſ.
speech.line: Madame, with all my heart,
I ſhall obey you in all faire commands.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: My people dœ already know my minde,
And will acknowledge you and Ieſſica
In place of Lord Baſſanio and my ſelfe.
So far you well till we ſhall meete againe.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Faire thoughts & happy houres attend on you.

speech.speaker: Ieſſi.
speech.line: I wiſh your Ladiſhip all hearts content.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I thanke you for your wiſh, and am well pleas’d
To wiſh it backe on you: faryouwell Ieſſica.Exeunt.
Now Balthaſer, as I haue euer found thee honeſt true,
So let me ﬁnde thee ſtill: take this ſame letter,
And vſe thou all the indeauor of a man,
In ſpeed to Mantua, ſee thou render this
Into my coſins hand, Doƈtor Belario,
And looke what notes and garments he doth giue thee,
Bring them I pray thee with imagin’d ſpeed
Vnto the Traneƈt, to the common Ferrie
Which trades to Venice; waſte no time in words,
But get thee gone, I ſhall be there before thee.

speech.speaker: Balth.
speech.line: Madam, I gœ with all conuenient ſpeed.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Come on Neriſſa, I haue worke in hand
That you yet know not of; wee’ll ſee our husbands
Before they thinke of vs?

speech.speaker: Nerriſſa.
speech.line: Shall they ſee vs?

speech.speaker: Portia.
speech.line: They ſhall Nerriſſa: but in ſuch a habit,
That they ſhall thinke we are accompliſhed
With that we lacke; Ile hold thee any wager
When we are both accoutered like yong men,
Ile proue the prettier fellow of the two,
And weare my dagger with the brauer grace,
And ſpeake betweene the change of man and boy,
With a reede voyce, and turne two minſing ſteps
Into a manly ſtride; and ſpeake of frayes
Like a ﬁne bragging youth: and tell quaint lyes
How honourable Ladies ſought my loue,
Which I denying, they fell ſicke and died.
I could not dœ withall: then Ile repent,
And wiſh for all that, that I had not kil’d them;
And twentie of theſe punie lies Ile tell,
That men ſhall ſweare I haue diſcontinued ſchoole
Aboue a twelue moneth: I haue within my minde
A thouſand raw tricks of theſe bragging Iacks,
Which I will praƈtiſe.

speech.speaker: Nerriſ.
speech.line: Why, ſhall wee turne to men?

speech.speaker: Portia.
speech.line: Fie, what a queſtions that?
If thou wert nere a lewd interpreter:
But come, Ile tell thee all my whole deuice
When I am in my coach, which ſtayes for vs
At the Parke gate; and therefore haſte away,
For we muſt meaſure twentie miles to day.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Clown.
speech.line: Yes truly; for looke you, the ſinnes of the Fa-
ther are to be laid vpon the children, therefore I promiſe
you, I feare you, I was alwaies plaine with you, and ſo
now I ſpeake my agitation of the matter: therfore be of
good cheere, for truly I thinke you are damn’d, there is
but one hope in it that can dœ you anie good, and that is
but a kinde of baſtard hope neither.

speech.speaker: Ieſſica.
speech.line: And what hope is that I pray thee?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Marrie you may partlie hope that your father
got you not, that you are not the Iewes daughter.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: That were a kinde of baſtard hope indeed, ſo the
ſins of my mother ſhould be viſited vpon me.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Truly then I feare you are damned both by fa-
ther and mother: thus when I ſhun Scilla your father, I
fall into Charibdis your mother; well, you are gone both
waies.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: I ſhall be ſau’d by my husband, he hath made me
a Chriſtian.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Truly the more to blame he, we were Chriſti-
ans enow before, e’ne as many as could wel liue one by a-
nother: this making of Chriſtians will raiſe the price of
Hogs, if wee grow all to be porke-eaters, wee ſhall not
ſhortlie haue a raſher on the coales for money.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Ile tell my husband Lancelet what you ſay, heere
he comes.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: I ſhall grow iealous of you ſhortly Lancelet,
if you thus get my wife into corners?

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Nay, you need not feare vs Lorenzo, Launcelet
and I are out, he tells me ﬂatly there is no mercy for mee
in heauen, becauſe I am a Iewes daughter: and hee ſaies
you are no good member of the common wealth, for
in conuerting Iewes to Chriſtians, you raiſe the price
of Porke.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: I ſhall anſwere that better to the Common-
wealth, than you can the getting vp of the Negrœs bel-
lie: the Moore is with childe by you Launcelet?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: It is much that the Moore ſhould be more then
reaſon: but if ſhe be leſſe then an honeſt woman, ſhee is
indeed more then I tooke her for.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: How euerie foole can play vpon the word, I
thinke the beſt grace of witte will ſhortly turne into ſi-
lence, and diſcourſe grow commendable in none onely
but Parrats: gœ in ſirra, bid them prepare for dinner?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: That is done ſir, they haue all ſtomacks?

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Goodly Lord, what a witte-ſnapper are you,
then bid them prepare dinner.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: That is done to ſir, onely couer is the word.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Will you couer than ſir?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Not ſo ſir neither, I know my dutie.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Yet more quarreling with occaſion, wilt thou
ſhew the whole wealth of thy wit in an inſtant; I pray
thee vnderſtand a plaine man in his plaine meaning: gœ
to thy fellowes, bid them couer the table, ſerue in the
meat, and we will come in to dinner.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: For the table ſir, it ſhall be ſeru’d in, for the
meat ſir, it ſhall bee couered, for your comming in to
dinner ſir, why let it be as humors and conceits ſhall go-
uerne.Exit Clowne.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: O deare diſcretion, how his words are ſuted,
The foole hath planted in his memory
An Armie of good words, and I dœ know
A many fooles that ſtand in better place,
Garniſht like him, that for a trickſie word
Deﬁe the matter: how cheer’ſt thou Ieſſica,
And now good ſweet ſay thy opinion,
How doſt thou like the Lord Baſſiano’s wife?

speech.speaker: Ieſſi.
speech.line: Paſt all expreſſing, it is very meete
The Lord Baſſanio liue an vpright life
For hauing ſuch a bleſſing in his Lady,
He ﬁndes the ioyes of heauen heere on earth,
And if on earth he dœ not meane it, it
Is reaſon he ſhould neuer come to heauen?
Why, if two gods ſhould play ſome heauenly match,
And on the wager lay two earthly women,
And Portia one: there muſt be ſomething elſe
Paund with the other, for the poore rude world
Hath not her fellow.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Euen ſuch a husband
Haſt thou of me, as ſhe is for a wife.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Nay, but aske my opinion to of that?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: I will anone, ﬁrſt let vs gœ to dinner?

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: Nay, let me praiſe you while I haue a ſtomacke?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: No pray thee, let it ſerue for table talke,
Then how ſom ere thou ſpeakſt ’mong other things,
I ſhall digeſt it?

speech.speaker: Ieſſi
speech.line: Well, Ile ſet you forth.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Duke, the Magniﬁcœs, Anthonio, Baſſanio, and Gratiano

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What, is Anthonio heere?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Ready, ſo pleaſe your grace?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I am ſorry for thee, thou art come to anſwere
A ſtonie aduerſary, an inhumane wretch,
Vncapable of pitty, voyd, and empty
From any dram of mercie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I haue heard
Your Grace hath tane great paines to qualiﬁe
His rigorous courſe: but ſince he ſtands obdurate,
And that no lawful meanes can carrie me
Out of his enuies reach, I do oppoſe
My patience to his fury, and am arm’d
To ſuffer with a quietneſſe of ſpirit,
The very tiranny and rage of his.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Go one and cal the Iew into the Court.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: He is ready at the doore, he comes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Make roome, and let him ſtand before our face.
Shylocke the world thinkes, and I thinke ſo to
That thou but leadeſt this faſhion of thy mallice
To the laſt houre of aƈt, and then ’tis thought
Thou’lt ſhew thy mercy and remorſe more ſtrange,
Than is thy ſtrange apparant cruelty;
And where thou now exaƈt’ſt the penalty,
Which is a pound of this poore Merchants ﬂeſh,
Thou wilt not onely looſe the forfeiture,
But touch’d with humane gentleneſſe and loue:
Forgiue a moytie of the principall,
Glancing an eye of pitty on his loſſes
That haue of late ſo hudled on his backe,
Enow to preſſe a royall Merchant downe;
And plucke commiſeration of his ſtate
From braſſie boſomes, and rough hearts of ﬂints,
From ſtubborne Turkes and Tarters neuer traind
To ofﬁces of tender curteſie,
We all expeƈt a gentle anſwer Iew?

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I haue poſſeſt your grace of what I purpoſe,
And by our holy Sabbath haue I ſworne
To haue the due and forfeit of my bond.
If you denie it, let the danger light
Vpon your Charter, and your Cities freedome.
You’l aske me why I rather chooſe to haue
A weight of carrion ﬂeſh, then to receiue
Three thouſand Ducats? Ile not anſwer that:
But ſay it is my humor; Is it anſwered?
What if my houſe be troubled with a Rat,
And I be pleas’d to giue ten thouſand Ducates
To haue it bain’d? What, are you anſwer’d yet?
Some men there are loue not a gaping Pigge:
Some that are mad, if they behold a Cat:
And others, when the bag-pipe ſings i’th noſe,
Cannot containe their Vrine for affeƈtion.
Maſters of paſſion ſwayes it to the moode
Of what it likes or loaths, now for your anſwer:
As there is no ﬁrme reaſon to be rendred
Why he cannot abide a gaping Pigge?
Why he a harmleſſe neceſſarie Cat?
Why he a woollen bag-pipe: but of force
Muſt yeeld to ſuch ineuitable ſhame,
As to offend himſelfe being offended:
So can I giue no reaſon, nor I will not,
More then a lodg’d hate, and a certaine loathing
I beare Anthonio, that I follow thus
A looſing ſuite againſt him? Are you anſwered?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: This is no anſwer thou vnfeeling man,
To excuſe the currant of thy cruelty.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I am not bound to pleaſe thee with my anſwer.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Do all men kil the things they do not loue?

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Hates any man the thing he would not kill?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Euerie offence is not a hate at ﬁrſt.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: What wouldſt thou haue a Serpent ſting thee
twice?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I pray you thinke you queſtion with the Iew:
You may as well go ſtand vpon the beach,
And bid the maine ﬂood baite his vſuall height,
Or euen as well vſe queſtion with the Wolfe,
The Ewe bleate for the Lambe:
You may as well forbid the Mountaine Pines
To wagge their high tops, and to make no noiſe
When they are fretted with the guſts of heauen:
You may as well do any thing moſt hard,
As ſeeke to ſoﬅen that, then which what harder?
His Iewiſh heart. Therefore I do beſeech you
Make no more offers, vſe no farther meanes,
But with all briefe and plaine conueniencie
Let me haue iudgement, and the Iew his will.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: For thy three thouſand Ducates heereis ſix.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: If euerie Ducat in ſixe thouſand Ducates
Were in ſixe parts, and euery part a Ducate,
I would not draw them, I would haue my bond?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: How ſhalt thou hope for mercie, rendring none?

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: What iudgement ſhall I dread doing no wrong?
You haue among you many a purchaſt ſlaue,
Which like your Aſſes, and your Dogs and Mules,
You vſe in abieƈt and in ſlauiſh parts,
Becauſe you bought them. Shall I ſay to you,
Let them be free, marrie them to your heires?
Why ſweate they vnder burthens? Let their beds
Be made as ſoﬅ as yours: and let their pallats
Be ſeaſon’d with ſuch Viands: you will anſwer
The ſlaues are ours. So do I anſwer you.
The pound of ﬂeſh which I demand of him
Is deerely bought, ’tis mine, and I will haue it.
If you deny me; ﬁe vpon your Law,
There is no force in the decrees of Venice;
I ſtand for iudgement, anſwer, Shall I haue it?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Vpon my power I may diſmiſſe this Court,
Vnleſſe Bellario a learned Doƈtor,
Whom I haue ſent for to determine this,
Come heere to day.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: My Lord, heere ſtayes without
A Meſſenger with Letters from the Doƈtor,
New come from Padua.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Bring vs the Letters, Call the Meſſengers.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Good cheere Anthonio. What man, corage yet:
The Iew ſhall haue my ﬂeſh, blood, bones, and all,
Ere thou ſhalt looſe for me one drop of blood.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I am a tainted Weather of the ﬂocke,
Meeteſt for death, the weakeſt kinde of fruite
Drops earlieſt to the ground, and ſo let me;
You cannot better be employ’d Baſſanio,
Then to liue ſtill, and write mine Epitaph.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Came you from Padua from Bellario?

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: From both.
My Lord Bellario greets your Grace.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Why doſt thou whet thy knife ſo earneſtly?

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrout there.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Not on thy ſoale: but on thy ſoule harſh Iew
Thou mak’ſt thy knife keene: but no mettall can,
No, not the hangmans Axe beare halfe the keenneſſe
Of thy ſharpe enuy. Can no prayers pierce thee?

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: No, none that thou haſt wit enough to make.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: O be thou damn’d, inexecrable dogge,
And for thy life let iuſtice be accus’d:
Thou almoſt mak’ſt me wauer in my faith;
To hold opinion with Pythagoras,
That ſoules of Animals infuſe themſelues
Into the trunkes of men. Thy curriſh ſpirit
Gouern’d a Wolfe, who hang’d for humane ſlaughter,
Euen from the gallowes did his fell ſoule ﬂeet;
And whil’ſt thou layeſt in thy vnhallowed dam,
Infus’d it ſelfe in thee: For thy deſires
Are Woluiſh, bloody, ſteru’d, and rauenous.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Till thou canſt raile the ſeale from off my bond
Thou but offend’ſt thy Lungs to ſpeake ſo loud:
Repaire thy wit good youth, or it will fall
To endleſſe ruine. I ſtand heere for Law.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: This Letter from Bellario doth commend
A yong and Learned Doƈtor in our Court;
Where is he?

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: He attendeth heere hard by
To know your anſwer, whether you’l admit him.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: With all my heart. Some three or four of you
Go giue him curteous conduƈt to this place,
Meane time the Court ſhall heare Bellariœs Letter.

line.italic: Your Grace ſhall vnderſtand, that at the receite of your
Letter I am very ſicke: but in the inſtant that your meſ-
ſenger came, in louing viſitation, was with me a yong Do-
ƈtor of Rome, his name is Balthaſar: I acquainted him with
the cauſe in Controuerſie, betweene the Iew and Anthonio
the Merchant: We turn’d ore many Bookes together: hee is
furniſhed with my opinion, which bettred with his owne lear-
ning, the greatneſſe whereof I cannot enough commend, comes
with him at my importunity, to ﬁll vp your Graces requeſt in
my ſted. I beſeech you, let his lacke of years be no impediment
to let him lacke a reuerend eſtimation: for I neuer knewe ſo
yong a body, with ſo old a head. I leaue him to your gracious
acceptance, whoſe trial ſhall better publiſh his commendation.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You heare the learn’d Bellario what he writes,
And heere (I take it) is the Doƈtor come.
Giue me your hand: Came you from old Bellario?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I did my Lord.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: You are welcome: take your place;
Are you acquainted with the difference
That holds this preſent queſtion in the Court.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I am enformed throughly of the cauſe.
Which is the Merchant heere? and which the Iew?

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Anthonio and old Shylocke, both ſtand forth.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Is your name Shylocke?

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Shylocke is my name.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Of a ſtrange nature is the ſute you follow,
Yet in ſuch rule, that the Venetian Law
Cannot impugne you as you do proceed.
You ſtand within his danger, do you not?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I, ſo he ſayes.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Do you confeſſe the bond?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I do.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Then muſt the Iew be mercifull.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: On what compulſion muſt I ? Tell me that.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: The quality of mercy is not ſtrain’d,
It droppeth as the gentle raine from heauen
Vpon the place beneath. It is twice bleſt,
It bleſſeth him that giues, and him that takes,
’Tis mightieſt in the mightieſt, it becomes
The throned Monarch better then his Crowne.
His Scepter ſhewes the force of temporall power,
The attribute to awe and Maieſtie,
Wherein doth ſit the dread and feare of Kings:
But mercy is aboue this ſceptred ſway,
It is enthroned in the hearts of Kings,
It is an attribute to God himſelfe;
And earthly power doth then ſhew likeſt Gods
When mercie ſeaſons Iuſtice. Therefore Iew,
Though Iuſtice be thy plea, conſider this,
That in the courſe of Iuſtice, none of vs
Should ſee ſaluation: we do pray for mercie,
And that ſame prayer, doth teach vs all to render
The deeds of mercie. I haue ſpoke thus much
To mittigate the iuſtice of thy plea:
Which if thou follow, this ſtriƈt courſe of Venice
Muſt needes giue ſentence ’gainſt the Merchant there.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: My deeds vpon my head, I craue the Law,
The penaltie and forfeite of my bond.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Is he not able to diſcharge the money?

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Yes, heere I tender it for him in the Court,
Yea, twice the ſumme, if that will not ſufﬁce,
I will be bound to pay it ten times ore,
On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart:
If this will not ſufﬁce, it muſt appeare
That malice beares downe truth. And I beſeech you
Wreſt once the Law to your authority.
To do a great right, do a little wrong,
And curbe this cruell diuell of his will.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: It muſt not be, there is no power in Venice
Can alter a decree eſtabliſhed:
’Twill be recorded for a Preſident,
And many an error by the ſame example,
Will ruſh into the ſtate: It cannot be.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: A Daniel come to iudgement, yea a Daniel.
O wiſe young Iudge, how do I honour thee.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I pray you let me looke vpon the bond.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Heere ’tis moſt reuerend Doƈtor, heere it is.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Shylocke, there’s thrice thy monie offered thee.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: An oath, an oath, I haue an oath in heauen:
Shall I lay periurie vpon my ſoule?
No not for Venice.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Why this bond is forfeit,
And lawfully by this the Iew may claime
A pound of ﬂeſh, to be by him cut off
Neereſt the Merchants heart; be mercifull,
Take thrice thy money, bid me teare the bond.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: When it is paid according to the tenure.
It doth appeare you are a worthy Iudge:
You know the Law, your expoſition
Hath beene moſt ſound. I charge you by the Law,
Whereof you are a well-deſeruing pillar,
Proceede to iudgement: By my ſoule I ſweare,
There is no power in the tongue of man
To alter me: I ſtay heere on my bond.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Moſt heartily I do beſeech the Court
To giue the iudgement.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Why then thus it is:
You muſt prepare your boſome for his knife.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: O noble Iudge, O excellent yong man.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: For the intent and purpoſe of the Law
Hath full relation to the penaltie,
Which heere appeareth due vpon the bond.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: ’Tis verie true: O wiſe and vpright Iudge,
How much more elder art thou then thy lookes?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Therefore lay bare your boſome.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I, his breſt,
So ſayes the bond, doth it not noble Iudge?
Neereſt his heart, thoſe are the very words.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: It is ſo: Are there ballance heere to weigh the
ﬂeſh?

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I haue them ready.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Haue by ſome Surgeon Shylock on your charge
To ſtop his wounds, leaſt he ſhould bleede to death.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: It is not nominated in the bond?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: It is not ſo expreſt: but what of that?
’Twere good you do ſo much for charitie.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I cannot ﬁnde it, ’tis not in the bond.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Come Merchant, haue you any thing to ſay?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: But little: I am arm’d and well prepar’d.
Giue me your hand Baſſanio, fare you well.
Greeue not that I am falne to this for you:
For heerein fortune ſhewes her ſelfe more kinde
Then is her cuſtome. It is ſtill her vſe
To let the wretched man out-liue his wealth,
To view with hollow eye, and wrinkled brow
An age of pouerty. From which lingring penance
Of ſuch miſerie, doth ſhe cut me off:
Commend me to your honourable Wife,
Tell her the proceſſe of Anthonio’s end:
Say how I lou’d you; ſpeake me faire in death:
And when the tale is told, bid her be iudge,
Whether Baſſanio had not once a Loue:
Repent not you that you ſhall looſe your friend,
And he repents not that he payes your debt.
For if the Iew do cut but deepe enough,
Ile pay it inſtantly, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Anthonio, I am married to a wife,
Which is as deere to me as life it ſelfe,
But life it ſelfe, my wife, and all the world,
Are not with me eſteem’d aboue thy life.
I would looſe all, I ſacriﬁce them all
Heere to this deuill, to deliuer you.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Your wife would giue you little thanks for that
If ſhe were by to heare you make the offer.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: I haue a wife whom I proteſt I loue,
I would ſhe were in heauen, ſo ſhe could
Intreat ſome power to change this curriſh Iew.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: ’Tis well you offer it behinde her backe,
The wiſh would make elſe an vnquiet houſe.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Theſe be the Chriſtian husbands: I haue a daughter
Would any of the ſtocke of Barrabas
Had beene her husband, rather then a Chriſtian.
We triﬂe time, I pray thee purſue ſentence.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: A pound of that ſame marchants ﬂeſh is thine,
The Court awards it, and the law doth giue it.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Moſt rightfull Iudge.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: And you muſt cut this ﬂeſh from off his breaſt,
The Law allowes it, and the Court awards it.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Moſt learned Iudge, a ſentence, come prepare.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Tarry a little, there is ſomething elſe,
This bond doth giue thee heere no iot of bloud,
The words expreſly are a pound of ﬂeſh:
Then take thy bond, take thou thy pound of ﬂeſh,
But in the cutting it, if thou doſt ſhed
One drop of Chriſtian bloud, thy lands and goods
Are by the Lawes of Venice conﬁſcate
Vnto the ſtate of Venice.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: O vpright Iudge,
Marke Iew, ō learned Iudge.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Is that the law?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Thy ſelfe ſhalt ſee the Aƈt:
For as thou vrgeſt iuſtice, be aſſur’d
Thou ſhalt haue iuſtice more then thou deſireſt.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: O learned Iudge, mark Iew, a learned Iudge.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I take this offer then, pay the bond thrice,
And let the Chriſtian gœ.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Heere is the money.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Soﬅ, the Iew ſhall haue all iuſtice, ſoﬅ, no haſte,
He ſhall haue nothing but the penalty.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: O Iew, an vpright Iudge, a learned Iudge.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the ﬂeſh,
Shed thou no bloud, nor cut thou leſſe nor more
But iuſt a pound of ﬂeſh: if thou tak’ſt more
Or leſſe then a iuſt pound, be it ſo much
As makes it light or heauy in the ſubſtance,
Or the deuiſion of the twentieth part
Of one poore ſcruple, nay if the ſcale dœ turne
But in the eſtimation of a hayre,
Thou dieſt, and all thy goods are conﬁſcate.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: A ſecond Daniel, a Daniel Iew,
Now inﬁdell I haue thee on the hip.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Why doth the Iew pauſe, take thy forfeiture.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Giue me my principall, and let me gœ.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: I haue it ready for thee, heere it is.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: He hath refus’d it in the open Court,
He ſhall haue meerly iuſtice and his bond.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: A Daniel ſtill ſay I, a ſecond Daniel,
I thanke thee Iew for teaching me that word.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Shall I not haue barely my principall?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt haue nothing but the forfeiture,
To be taken ſo at thy perill Iew.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Why then the Deuill giue him good of it:
Ile ſtay no longer queſtion.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Tarry Iew,
The Law hath yet another hold on you.
It is enaƈted in the Lawes of Venice,
If it be proued againſt an Alien,
That by direƈt, or indireƈt attempts
He ſeeke the life of any Citizen,
The party gainſt the which he doth contriue,
Shall ſeaze one halfe his goods, the other halfe
Comes to the priuie coffer of the State,
And the offenders life lies in the mercy
Of the Duke onely, gainſt all other voice.
In which predicament I ſay thou ſtandſt:
For it appeares by manifeſt proceeding,
That indireƈtly, and direƈtly to,
Thou haſt contriu’d againſt the very life
Of the defendant: and thou haſt incur’d
The danger formerly by me rehearſt.
Downe therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Beg that thou maiſt haue leaue to hang thy ſelfe,
And yet thy wealth being forfeit to the ſtate,
Thou haſt not leﬅ the value of a cord,
Therefore thou muſt be hang’d at the ſtates charge.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: That thou ſhalt ſee the difference of our ſpirit,
I pardon thee thy life before thou aske it:
For halfe thy wealth, it is Anthonio’s
The other halfe comes to the generall ſtate,
Which humbleneſſe may driue vnto a ﬁne.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I for the ſtate, not for Anthonio.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: Nay, take my life and all, pardon not that,
You take my houſe, when you do take the prop
That doth ſuſtaine my houſe: you take my life
When you dœ take the meanes whereby I liue.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: What mercy can you render him Anthonio?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: A halter gratis, nothing elſe for Gods ſake.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: So pleaſe my Lord the Duke, and all the Court
To quit the ﬁne for one halfe of his goods,
I am content: ſo he will let me haue
The other halfe in vſe, to render it
Vpon his death, vnto the Gentleman
That lately ſtole his daughter.
Two things prouided more, that for this fauour
He preſently become a Chriſtian:
The other, that he dœ record a giﬅ
Heere in the Court of all he dies poſſeſt
Vnto his ſonne Lorenzo, and his daughter.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: He ſhall dœ this, or elſe I dœ recant
The pardon that I late pronounced heere.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Art thou contented Iew? what doſt thou ſay?

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I am content.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Clarke, draw a deed of giﬅ.

speech.speaker: Shy.
speech.line: I pray you giue me leaue to gœ from hence,
I am not well, ſend the deed aﬅer me,
And I will ſigne it.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Get thee gone, but dœ it.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: In chriſtning thou ſhalt haue two godfathers,
Had I been iudge, thou ſhouldſt haue had ten more,
To bring thee to the gallowes, not to the font.Exit.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Sir I intreat you with me home to dinner.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I humbly dœ deſire your Grace of pardon,
I muſt away this night toward Padua,
And it is meete I preſently ſet forth.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: I am ſorry that your leyſure ſerues you not:
Anthonio, gratiﬁe this gentleman,
For in my minde you are much bound to him.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Moſt worthy gentleman, I and my friend
Haue by your wiſedome beene this day acquitted
Of greeuous penalties, in lieu whereof,
Three thouſand Ducats due vnto the Iew
We freely cope your curteous paines withall.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: And ſtand indebted ouer and aboue
In loue and ſeruice to you euermore.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: He is well paid that is well ſatisﬁed,
And I deliuering you, am ſatisﬁed,
And therein dœ account my ſelfe well paid,
My minde was neuer yet more mercinarie.
I pray you know me when we meete againe,
I wiſh you well, and ſo I take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Deare ſir, of force I muſt attempt you further,
Take ſome remembrance of vs as a tribute,
Not as fee: grant me two things, I pray you
Not to denie me, and to pardon me.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: You preſſe mee farre, and therefore I will yeeld,
Giue me your gloues, Ile weare them for your ſake,
And for your loue Ile take this ring from you,
Dœ not draw backe your hand, ile take no more,
And you in loue ſhall not deny me this?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: This ring good ſir, alas it is a triﬂe,
I will not ſhame my ſelfe to giue you this.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I wil haue nothing elſe but onely this,
And now methinkes I haue a minde to it.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: There’s more depends on this then on the valew,
The deareſt ring in Venice will I giue you,
And ﬁnde it out by proclamation,
Onely for this I pray you pardon me.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I ſee ſir you are liberall in offers,
You taught me ﬁrſt to beg, and now me thinkes
You teach me how a beggar ſhould be anſwer’d.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Good ſir, this ring was giuen me by my wife,
And when ſhe put it on, ſhe made me vow
That I ſhould neither ſell, nor giue, nor loſe it.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: That ſcuſe ſerues many men to ſaue their giﬅs,
And if your wife be not a mad woman,
And know how well I haue deſeru’d this ring,
Shee would not hold out enemy for euer
For giuing it to me: well, peace be with you.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: My L.Baſſanio, let him haue the ring,
Let his deſeruings and my loue withall
Be valued againſt your wiues commandement.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Gœ Gratiano, run and ouer-take him,
Giue him the ring, and bring him if thou canſt
Vnto Anthonios houſe, away, make haſte.Exit Grati.
Come, you and I will thither preſently,
And in the morning early will we both
Flie toward Belmont, come Anthonio.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Enquire the Iewes houſe out, giue him this deed,
And let him ſigne it, wee’ll away to night,
And be a day before our husbands home:
This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Faire ſir, you are well ore-tane:
My L.Baſſanio vpon more aduice,
Hath ſent you heere this ring, and doth intreat
Your company at dinner.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: That cannot be;
His ring I dœ accept moſt thankfully,
And ſo I pray you tell him: furthermore,
I pray you ſhew my youth old Shylockes houſe.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: That will I dœ.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Sir, I would ſpeake with you:
Ile ſee if I can get my husbands ring
Which I did make him ſweare to keepe for euer.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Thou maiſt I warrant, we ſhal haue old ſwearing
That they did giue the rings away to men;
But weele out-face them, and out-ſweare them to:
Away, make haſte, thou know’ſt where I will tarry.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Come good ſir, will you ſhew me to this houſe.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: The moone ſhines bright. In ſuch a night as this,
When the ſweet winde did gently kiſſe the trees,
And they did make no noyſe, in ſuch a night
Troylus me thinkes mounted the Troian walls,
And ſigh’d his ſoule toward the Grecian tents
Where Creſſed lay that night.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: In ſuch a night
Did Thisbie fearefully ore-trip the dewe,
And ſaw the Lyons ſhadow ere himſelfe,
And ranne diſmayed away.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: In ſuch a night
Stood Dido with a Willow in her hand
Vpon the wilde ſea bankes, and waﬅ her Loue
To come againe to Carthage.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: In ſuch a night
Medea gathered the inchanted hearbs
That did renew old Eſon.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: In ſuch a night
Did Ieſſica ſteale from the wealthy Iewe,
And with an Vnthriﬅ Loue did runne from Venice,
As farre as Belmont.

speech.speaker: Ieſ.
speech.line: In ſuch a night
Did young Lorenzo ſweare he lou’d her well,
Stealing her ſoule with many vowes of faith,
And nere a true one.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: In ſuch a night
Did pretty Ieſſica (like a little ſhrow)
Slander her Loue, and he forgaue it her.

speech.speaker: Ieſſi.
speech.line: I would out-night you did no body come:
But harke, I heare the footing of a man.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Who comes ſo faſt in ſilence of the night?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: A friend.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: A friend, what friend? your name I pray you friend?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Stephano is my name, and I bring word
My Miſtreſſe will before the breake of day
Be heere at Belmont, ſhe doth ſtray about
By holy croſſes where ſhe kneeles and prayes
For happy wedlocke houres.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Who comes with her?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: None but a holy Hermit and her maid:
I pray you it my Maſter yet return’d?

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: He is not, nor we haue not heard from him,
But gœ we in I pray thee Ieſſica,
And ceremoniouſly let vs vs prepare
Some welcome for the Miſtreſſe of the houſe,

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sola, ſola: wo ha ho, ſola, ſola.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Who calls?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sola, did you ſee M.Lorenzo, & M.Lorenzo, ſola,ſola.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Leaue hollowing man, heere.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sola, where, where?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Heere?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Tel him ther’s a Poſt come from my Maſter, with
his horne full of good newes, my Maſter will be here ere
morning ſweete ſoule.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Let’s in, and there expeƈt their comming.
And yet no matter: why ſhould we gœ in?
My friend Stephen, ſigniﬁe pray you
Within the houſe, your Miſtreſſe is at hand,
And bring your muſique foorth into the ayre.
How ſweet the moone-light ſleepes vpon this banke,
Heere will we ſit, and let the ſounds of muſicke
Creepe in our eares ſoﬅ ſtilnes, and the night
Become the tutches of ſweet harmonie:
Sit Ieſſica, looke how the ﬂoore of heauen
Is thicke inlayed with pattens of bright gold,
There’s not the ſmalleſt orbe which thou beholdſt
But in his motion like an Angell ſings,
Still quiring to the young eyed Cherubins;
Such harmonie is in immortall ſoules,
But whilſt this muddy veſture of decay
Doth groſly cloſe in it, we cannot heare it:
Come hœ, and wake Diana with a hymne,
With ſweeteſt tutches pearce your Miſtreſſe eare,
And draw her home with muſicke.

speech.speaker: Ieſſi.
speech.line: I am neuer merry when I heare ſweet muſique.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: The reaſon is, your ſpirits are attentiue:
For dœ but note a wilde and wanton heard
Or race of youthful and vnhandled colts,
Fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neighing loud,
Which is the hot condition of their bloud,
If they but heare perchance a trumpet ſound,
Or any ayre of muſicke touch their eares,
You ſhall perceiue them make a mutuall ſtand,
Their ſauage eyes turn’d to a modeſt gaze,
By the ſweet power of muſicke: therefore the Pœt
Did faine that Orpheus drew trees, ſtones, and ﬂoods.
Since naught ſo ſtockiſh, hard, and full of rage,
But muſicke for time doth change his nature,
The man that hath no muſicke in himſelfe,
Nor is not moued with concord of ſweet ſounds,
Is ﬁt for treaſons, ſtratagems, and ſpoyles,
The motions of his ſpirit are dull as night,
And his affeƈtions darke as Erobus,
Let no ſuch man be truſted: marke the muſicke.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: That light we ſee is burning in my hall:
How farre that little candell throwes his beames,
So ſhines a good deed in a naughty world.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: When the moone ſhone we did not ſee the candle?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: So doth the greater glory dim the leſſe,
A ſubſtitute ſhines brightly as a King
Vntill a King be by, and then his ſtate
Empties it ſelfe, as doth an inland brooke
Into the maine of waters: muſique, harke.Muſicke.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: It is your muſicke Madame of the houſe.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Nothing is good I ſee without reſpeƈt,
Methinkes it ſounds much ſweeter then by day?

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Silence beſtowes that vertue on it Madam.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: The Crow doth ſing as ſweetly as the Larke
When neither is attended: and I thinke
The Nightingale if ſhe ſhould ſing by day
When euery Gooſe is cackling, would be thought
No better a Muſitian then the Wren?
How many things by ſeaſon, ſeaſon’d are
To their right praiſe, and true perfeƈtion:
Peace, how the Moone ſleepes with Endimion,
And would not be awak’d.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: That is the voice,
Or I am much deceiu’d of Portia.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: He knowes me as the blinde man knowes the
Cuckow by the bad voice?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Deere Lady welcome home?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: We haue bene praying for our husbands welfare
Which ſpeed we hope the better for our words,
Are they return’d?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Madam, they are not yet:
But there is come a Meſſenger before
To ſigniﬁe their comming.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Go in Nerriſſa,
Giue order to my ſeruants, that they take
No note at all of our being abſent hence,
Nor you Lorenzo, Ieſſica nor you.

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Your husband is at hand, I heare his Trumpet,
We are no tell-tales Madam, feare you not.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: This night methinkes is but the daylight ſicke,
It lookes a little paler, ’tis a day,
Such as the day is, when the Sun is hid.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baſſanio, Anthonio, Gratiano, and their Followers

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: We ſhould hold day with the Antipodes,
If you would walke in abſence of the ſunne.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Let me giue light, but let me not be light,
For a light wife doth make a heauie husband,
And neuer be Baſſanio ſo for me,
But God ſort all: you are welcome home my Lord.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: I thanke you Madam, giue welcom to my friend
This is the man, this is Anthonio,
To whom I am ſo inﬁnitely bound.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: You ſhould in all ſence be much bound to him,
For as I heare he was much bound for you.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: No more then I am wel acquitted of.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Sir, you are verie welcome to our houſe:
It muſt appeare in other waies then words,
Therefore I ſcant this breathing curteſie.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: By yonder Moone I ſweare you do me wrong,
Infaith I gaue it to the Iudges Clearke,
Would he were gelt that had it for my part,
Since you do take it Loue ſo much at hart.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: A quarrel hœ alreadie, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: About a hoope of Gold, a paltry Ring
That ſhe did giue me, whoſe Pœſie was
For all the world like Cutlers Pœtry
Vpon a knife; Loue mee, and leaue mee not.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: What talke you of the Pœſie or the valew:
You ſwore to me when I did giue it you,
That you would weare it til the houre of death,
And that it ſhould lye with you in your graue,
Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,
You ſhould haue beene reſpeƈtiue and haue kept it.
Gaue it a Iudges Clearke: but wel I know
The Clearke wil nere weare haire on’s face that had it.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: He wil, and if he liue to be a man.

speech.speaker: Nerriſſa.
speech.line: I, if a Woman liue to be a man.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Now by this hand I gaue it to a youth,
A kinde of boy, a little ſcrubbed boy,
No higher then thy ſelfe, the Iudges Clearke,
A prating boy that begg’d it as a Fee,
I could not for my heart deny it him.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: You were too blame, I muſt be plaine with you,
To part ſo ſlightly with your wiues ﬁrſt giﬅ,
A thing ſtucke on with oathes vpon your ﬁnger,
And ſo riueted with faith vnto your ﬂeſh.
I gaue my Loue a Ring, and made him ſweare
Neuer to part with it, and heere he ſtands:
I dare be ſworne for him, he would not leaue it,
Nor plucke it from his ﬁnger, for the wealth
That the world maſters. Now in faith Gratiano,
You giue your wife too vnkinde a cauſe of greefe,
And ’twere to me I ſhould be mad at it.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Why I were beſt to cut my leﬅ hand off,
And ſweare I loſt the Ring defending it.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: My Lord Baſſanio gaue his Ring away
Vnto the Iudge that beg’d it, and indeede
Deſeru’d it too: and then the Boy his Clearke
That tooke ſome paines in writing, he begg’d mine,
And neyther man nor maſter would take ought
But the two Rings.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: What Ring gaue you my Lord?
Not that I hope which you receiu’d of me.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: If I could adde a lie vnto a fault,
I would deny it: but you ſee my ﬁnger
Hath not the Ring vpon it, it is gone.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Euen ſo voide is your falſe heart of truth.
By heauen I wil nere come in your bed
Vntil I ſee the Ring.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: Nor I in yours, til I againe ſee mine.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Sweet Portia,
If you did know to whom I gaue the Ring,
If you did know for whom I gaue the Ring,
And would conceiue for what I gaue the Ring,
And how vnwillingly I leﬅ the Ring,
When nought would be accepted but the Ring,
You would abate the ſtrength of your diſpleaſure?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: If you had knowne the vertue of the Ring,
Or halfe her worthineſſe that gaue the Ring,
Or your owne honour to containe the Ring,
You would not then haue parted with the Ring:
What man is there ſo much vnreaſonable,
If you had pleas’d to haue defended it
With any termes of Zeale: wanted the modeſtie
To vrge the thing held as a ceremonie:
Nerriſſa teaches me what to beleeue,
Ile die for’t, but ſome Woman had the Ring?

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: No by mine honor Madam, by my ſoule
No Woman had it, but a ciuill Doƈtor,
Which did refuſe three thouſand Ducates of me,
And beg’d the Ring; the which I did denie him,
And ſuffer’d him to go diſpleas’d away:
Euen he that had held vp the verie life
Of my deere friend. What ſhould I ſay ſweete Lady?
I was inforc’d to ſend it aﬅer him,
I was beſet with ſhame and curteſie,
My honor would not let ingratitude
So much beſmeare it. Pardon me good Lady,
And by theſe bleſſed Candles of the night,
Had you bene there, I thinke you would haue beg’d
The Ring of me, to giue the worthie Doƈtor?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Let not that Doƈtor ere come neere my houſe,
Since he hath got the iewell that I loued,
And that which you did ſweare to keepe for me,
I will become as liberall as you,
Ile not deny him any thing I haue,
No, not my body, nor my husbands bed:
Know him I ſhall, I am well ſure of it.
Lie not a night from home. Watch me like Argos,
If you dœ not, if I be leﬅ alone,
Now by mine honour which is yet mine owne,
Ile haue the Doƈtor for my bedfellow.

speech.speaker: Nerriſſa.
speech.line: And I his Clarke: therefore be well aduis’d
How you dœ leaue me to mine owne proteƈtion.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Well, dœ you ſo: let not me take him then,
For if I dœ, ile mar the yong Clarks pen.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I am th’vnhappy ſubieƈt of theſe quarrels.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Sir, grieue not you,
You are welcome notwithſtanding.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Portia, forgiue me this enforced wrong,
And in the hearing of theſe manie friends
I ſweare to thee, euen by thine owne faire eyes
Wherein I ſee my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Marke you but that?
In both my eyes he doubly ſees himſelfe:
In each eye one, ſweare by your double ſelfe,
And there’s an oath of credit.

speech.speaker: Baſ.
speech.line: Nay, but heare me.
Pardon this fault, and by my ſoule I ſweare
I neuer more will breake an oath with thee.

speech.speaker: Anth.
speech.line: I once did lend my bodie for thy wealth,
Which but for him that had your husbands ring
Had quite miſcarried. I dare be bound againe,
My ſoule vpon the forfeit, that your Lord
Will neuer more breake faith aduiſedlie.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Then you ſhall be his ſuretie: giue him this,
And bid him keepe it better then the other.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Heere Lord Baſſanio, ſwear to keep this ring.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: By heauen it is the ſame I gaue the Doƈtor.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: I had it of him: pardon Baſſanio,
For by this ring the Doƈtor lay with me.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: And pardon me my gentle Gratiano,
For that ſame ſcrubbed boy the Doƈtors Clarke
In liew of this, laſt night did lye with me.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Why this is like the mending of high waies
In Sommer, where the waies are faire enough:
What, are we Cuckolds ere we haue deſeru’d it.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: Speake not ſo groſſely, you are all amaz’d;
Heere is a letter, reade it at your leyſure,
It comes from Padua from Bellario,
There you ſhall ﬁnde that Portia was the Doƈtor,
Nerriſſa there her Clarke. Lorenzo heere
Shall witneſſe I ſet forth as ſoone as you,
And but eu’n now return’d: I haue not yet
Entred my houſe. Anthonio you are welcome,
And I haue better newes in ſtore for you
Then you expeƈt: vnſeale this letter ſoone,
There you ſhall ﬁnde three of your Argoſies
Are richly come to harbour ſodainlie.
You ſhall not know by what ſtrange accident
I chanced on this letter.

speech.speaker: Antho.
speech.line: I am dumbe.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: Were you the Doƈtor, and I knew you not?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Were you the Clark that is to make me cuckold.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: I, but the Clark that neuer meanes to dœ it,
Vnleſſe he liue vntill he be a man.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: (Sweet Doƈtor) you ſhall be my bedfellow,
When I am abſent, then lie with my wife.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: (Sweet Ladie) you haue giuen me life & liuing;
For heere I reade for certaine that my ſhips
Are ſafelie come to Rode.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: How now Lorenzo?
My Clarke hath ſome good comforts to for you.

speech.speaker: Ner.
speech.line: I, and Ile giue them him without a fee.
There dœ I giue to you and Ieſſica
From the rich Iewe, a ſpeciall deed of giﬅ
Aﬅer his death, of all he dies poſſeſſ’d of.

speech.speaker: Loren.
speech.line: Faire Ladies you drop Manna in the way
Of ſtarued people.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: It is almoſt morning,
And yet I am ſure you are not ſatisﬁed
Of theſe euents at full. Let vs gœ in,
And charge vs there vpon intergatories,
And we will anſwer all things faithfully.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Let it be ſo, the ﬁrſt intergatory
That my Nerriſſa ſhall be ſworne on, is,
Whether till the next night ſhe had rather ſtay,
Or gœ to bed, now being two houres to day,
But were the day come, I ſhould wiſh it darke,
Till I were couching with the Doƈtors Clarke.
Well, while I liue, Ile feare no other thing
So ſore, as keeping ſafe Nerriſſas ring.
